entry.title: Codeforces Round 963 (Div. 2) 部分题目总结
entry.content:
本次比赛 链接。说实话出的比较糟糕，题目难度的梯度非常不均匀。

A, B, C 题没什么好说的，跳过。

D. Med-imize

题目大意

给定一个包含 n 个 int 的数组 a，给定 k。在 a 中，每次选择长度刚好为 k 的任意的连续子数组进行删除，删除至 a 长度小于等于 k 为止。求删除操作结束后数组 a 最大可能的中位数值。

解题思路

二分搜索答案 + 动态规划。

当输入数组长度小于等于 k 时，答案就是当前数组的中位数。

❓如何在不排序的情况下求出一个数组的中位数呢？二分查找。

  • 对每一个给定的值 x，建立另一个和 a 一样大的标签数组 b。
    • 当 x<=a[i] 时，标记 b[i]=1；反之 b[i]=-1。
    • 这样通过判断 b 数组和的正负性，我们就能判断 x 是否比中位数小了。

当 n>k 时，同理进行二分搜索答案。为了检查当前值是否小于最优可能解，我们只需使用动态规划求出 b 数组最大的和，检查其正负性。

❓如何用动归求 b 数组最大的和呢？

注意到每次删除完成后数组的长度为 m=((n-1)%k)+1。

注意到删除完成后的数组 a' 中的每一位一定来自于原数组：

a′[0],⋯ ,a′[m−1]⇐a[i0],⋯ ,a[im−1]a'[0],\cdots,a'[m-1]\Larr a[i_0],\cdots,a[i_{m-1}]a′[0],⋯,a′[m−1]⇐a[i0​],⋯,a[im−1​]

其中对应的原数组下标必须满足

i0≡0mod  ki1≡1mod  k⋮im−1≡m−1mod  ki_0\equiv0\mod k\\i_1\equiv1\mod k\\\vdots\\i_{m-1}\equiv m-1\mod ki0​≡0modki1​≡1modk⋮im−1​≡m−1modk

为何？因为每次刚好删除的是 a 中连续的 k 个，删除之后并不影响每个下标模 k 的结果。

令 dp[i] 表示数组 a 中前 i 个数字中选择满足下标要求的 k 个数对应 b 数组之和的最大值，综上可得动态规划递推关系：

  • dp[0]=b[0]
  • 如果 i%k==0&&i>0，dp[i]=max(dp[i-k],b[i])（有可能把 i 之前的所有全删除了，从 i 开始）
  • 否则
    • 如果 i<=k，dp[i]=dp[i-1]+b[i]。（只有选上当前数字）
    • 如果 i>k，dp[i]=max(dp[i-1]+b[i],dp[i-k])。（要么选当前数字，要么把包括这个数字之前总共 k 个数字都删了，选第 i-k 个数字）

最后只需检查 dp[n-1] 是否大于零即可。

参考代码

E. Xor-Grid Problem

题目大意

给一个 n×mn\times mn×m 的矩阵，两种操作：

  1. 选定第 iii 行，将该行的每一个数都替换成该数对应列的所有数的异或值；
  2. 选定第 jjj 列，将该列的每一个数都替换成该数对应行的所有数的异或值。

可以执行操作任意次。最后计算矩阵的“美丽值”：

beauty(a)=∑∣ax,y−ar,c∣beauty(a)=\sum|a_{x,y}-a_{r,c}|beauty(a)=∑∣ax,y​−ar,c​∣

对矩阵中任意两个共享一条边的格子。

求最小的“美丽值”。

解题思路

观察到：

  • 尝试连续对某一行进行两次相同的操作，发现结果不变
  • 尝试对第 iii 行进行操作，再尝试对第 i′i'i′ 行进行操作，发现 i′i'i′ 行上的数字刚好就是原始第 iii 行上的数字。

本质上相当于：

将原始的矩阵拓展一行一列变成 (n+1)×(m+1)(n+1)\times(m+1)(n+1)×(m+1)。a[i][m+1]a[i][m+1]a[i][m+1] 就是第 iii 行所有数的异或值，同理 a[n+1][j]a[n+1][j]a[n+1][j] 就是第 jjj 列所有数的异或值。

每一次操作就是将第 iii 行（或第 jjj 列）与第 n+1n+1n+1 行（或第 m+1m+1m+1 列）进行交换。妙蛙

现在问题就转化为行和列的排列问题。

接下来拆解美丽值，美丽值可以分为两部分，横向的相邻格和纵向的相邻格。（⚠️在操作结束之后，扩展的那一行/列就不要参与到美丽值的计算中了！）

计算 dr[u][v]dr[u][v]dr[u][v] 表示第 uuu 行和第 vvv 行的差值；dc[u][v]dc[u][v]dc[u][v] 表示对应列的差值。

因此美丽值可以转化为

∑i=2ndr[ri−1][ri]+∑i=2mdc[ci−1][ci]\sum_{i=2}^ndr[r_{i-1}][r_i]+\sum_{i=2}^mdc[c_{i-1}][c_i]i=2∑n​dr[ri−1​][ri​]+i=2∑m​dc[ci−1​][ci​]

dr,dcdr,dcdr,dc 可以看成两个邻接矩阵分别对应两张图。此问题等价于 TSP。

F. Dyn-scripted Robot

题目大意

有一个机器人初始位于平面坐标 (0,0)(0,0)(0,0) 上。给定一个长度为 nnn 的指令序列，让机器人上下左右移动。这个指令序列将执行 kkk 次。机器人被限制在高度为 hhh，宽度为 www 的一个矩形区域中。当机器人在边界上如果指令会导致出界，则立即将该方向上所有指令取反。比如当机器人位于右边界时，此时指令向右，则机器人自动将指令序列中所有的左指令变成右指令，右指令变成左指令。

求在整个过程中机器人回到原点的次数。

解题思路

Easy Version

n,w,h≤106,k≤nn,w,h\le10^6,k\le nn,w,h≤106,k≤n.

仔细思考，其实不用考虑反弹的情况，让机器人自由移动，出界的时候其实就相当于进入了一个镜像对称的空间。

其实就相当于有四面镜子分别摆放在矩形区域的四个边上，那么实际上 (2wc1,2hc2),c1,c2∈Z(2wc_1,2hc_2),c_1,c_2\in\mathbb Z(2wc1​,2hc2​),c1​,c2​∈Z 都可以视作原点。所以分别经过取模 2w,2h2w,2h2w,2h，机器人就限制在了长宽为 2w,2h2w,2h2w,2h 的矩形中。

记 (xi,yi)(x_i,y_i)(xi​,yi​) 为机器人执行第一遍指令序列时每一步所在的位置。则指令完成后机器人位于 (xn,yn)(x_n,y_n)(xn​,yn​)。

此后机器人在执行第 jjj 遍指令序列时的第 iii 个指令，所在的位置为 (jxn+xi,jyn+yi)(jx_n+x_i,jy_n+y_i)(jxn​+xi​,jyn​+yi​)。同时，需要满足

x≡0mod  2w⇒xi≡−jxnmod  2wy≡0mod  2h⇒yi≡−jynmod  2hx\equiv0\mod 2w\Rarr x_i\equiv-jx_n\mod 2w\\y\equiv0\mod 2h\Rarr y_i\equiv-jy_n\mod 2hx≡0mod2w⇒xi​≡−jxn​mod2wy≡0mod2h⇒yi​≡−jyn​mod2h

直接遍历 000 到 k−1k-1k−1，对每一遍指令序列满足同余关系数量求和。最终得到答案。

可以用 map 存储执行第一遍指令序列机器人位于长宽为 2w,2h2w,2h2w,2h 的矩形内每一个点的经过次数。

Hard Version

k≤1012k\le10^{12}k≤1012

kkk 的范围导致了不能遍历 kkk，猜想是在同余方程上做文章。

不会😭

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 6 Randomized Computation
entry.content:
What if Turing machine models have access to a source of randomness?

This would allow to compute more in same time/space, at the price of possibly not giving correct answer with small probability.

Current consensus: Randomization only gives

  • Polynomial saving in time
  • Constant factor saving in space

Because of hardness-based pseudo-random generator.

Exponential time: E=DTIME(2O(n))=UL−SIZE(2O(n))E=DTIME(2^{O(n)})=U_L-SIZE(2^{O(n)})E=DTIME(2O(n))=UL​−SIZE(2O(n)). (By corollary 2)

Recall that SIZE(2n/n)SIZE(2^n/n)SIZE(2n/n) includes every Boolean function on nnn variables, making non-uniform inclusion E⊆SIZE(2O(n))E\subseteq SIZE(2^{O(n)})E⊆SIZE(2O(n)).

Corresponding randomized complexity class BPPBPPBPP.

Theorem 33 (Impagliazzo and Wigderson). If there exists L∈EL\in EL∈E s.t. for every nnn and every Boolean circuit CCC computing LLL on input length nnn, the size of CCC must be 2Ω(n)2^{\Omega(n)}2Ω(n), then P=BPPP=BPPP=BPP.

Probabilistic Turing Machines

Give a probabilistic Turing machine an extra read-only and read-once tape which is pre-initialized with uniform and independent random bits. The tape head is allow to only stop or move forward.

Thus everything related to the Turing machines becomes a random variable.

Different kinds of Errors

Zero-sided error aka Las Vegas computation: Turing machine halt in a state “?” with small probability and require correct answer otherwise.

One-sided error: Turing machine may produce false negatives.

Two-sided error: Turing machine may produce false negatives and false positives.

📖Definition 19. Let MMM be a probabilistic Turing machine and LLL a language.

  • MMM computes LLL with zero-sided error if for all xxx we have Pr⁡[M(x)=?]≤14\Pr[M(x)=?]\le\frac{1}{4}Pr[M(x)=?]≤41​, that M(x)∈{yes,?}M(x)\in\{yes,?\}M(x)∈{yes,?} when x∈Lx\in Lx∈L, and that M(x)∈{no,?}M(x)\in\{no,?\}M(x)∈{no,?} when x∉Lx\not\in Lx∈L.
  • MMM computes LLL with one-sided error if for all x∈Lx\in Lx∈L we have Pr⁡[M(x)=yes]≥34\Pr[M(x)=yes]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=yes]≥43​ and for all x∉Lx\not\in Lx∈L we have M(x)=noM(x)=noM(x)=no.
  • MMM computes LLL with two-sided error if for all x∈Lx\in Lx∈L we have Pr⁡[M(x)=yes]≥34\Pr[M(x)=yes]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=yes]≥43​ and for all x∉Lx\not\in Lx∈L we have Pr⁡[M(x)=no]≥34\Pr[M(x)=no]\ge\frac{3}{4}Pr[M(x)=no]≥43​.

📖Definition 20. Let T:N→NT:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NT:N→N and S:N→NS:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NS:N→N be functions with T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n.

  • Then ZPTIME(T(n))ZPTIME(T(n))ZPTIME(T(n)), RTIME(T(n))RTIME(T(n))RTIME(T(n)) and BPTIME(T(n))BPTIME(T(n))BPTIME(T(n)) are the classes of languages computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded probabilistic Turing machine with zero-sided error, one-sided error and two-sided error respectively.
  • ZPSPACE(S(n))ZPSPACE(S(n))ZPSPACE(S(n)), RSPACE(S(n))RSPACE(S(n))RSPACE(S(n)) and BPSPACE(S(n))BPSPACE(S(n))BPSPACE(S(n)) are the classes of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded probabilistic Turing machine that always halt having zero-sided error, one-sided error and two-sided error respectively.

For space bounded randomized classes, we assume that the Turing machine always halts! Because otherwise these three classes would end up containing NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))!

Define log-space/polynomial time bounded classes:

ZPL=ZPSPACE(log⁡n)RP=RSPACE(log⁡n)BPL=BPSPACE(log⁡n)ZPP=ZPTIME(nO(1))RP=RTIME(nO(1))BPP=BPTIME(nO(1))ZPL=ZPSPACE(\log n)\\RP=RSPACE(\log n)\\BPL=BPSPACE(\log n)\\ZPP=ZPTIME(n^{O(1)})\\RP=RTIME(n^{O(1)})\\BPP=BPTIME(n^{O(1)})ZPL=ZPSPACE(logn)RP=RSPACE(logn)BPL=BPSPACE(logn)ZPP=ZPTIME(nO(1))RP=RTIME(nO(1))BPP=BPTIME(nO(1))

Trivially, L⊆ZPL⊆RL⊆BPLL\subseteq ZPL\subseteq RL\subseteq BPLL⊆ZPL⊆RL⊆BPL; P⊆ZPP⊆RP⊆BPPP\subseteq ZPP\subseteq RP\subseteq BPPP⊆ZPP⊆RP⊆BPP.

It’s also easy to see that RL⊆NLRL\subseteq NLRL⊆NL and RP⊆NPRP\subseteq NPRP⊆NP.

Simple upper bound for BPPBPPBPP (not tight): similar to theorem 10, BPP⊆PSPACEBPP\subseteq PSPACEBPP⊆PSPACE.

For BPLBPLBPL, BPL⊆DSPACE(log⁡3/2n)BPL\subseteq DSPACE(\log^{3/2}n)BPL⊆DSPACE(log3/2n).

Success Amplification

Error probability of 1/41/41/4 is large, but we can reduce it by independently running multiple times.

For zero-sided error, we won’t stop until we get non-unknown answer.

For one-sided error, if some trial accepts, we accept. otherwise we reject.

For two-sided error, we decided the answer by the majority of trials.

🤔Lemma 3. Let X1,⋯ ,XkX_1,\cdots,X_kX1​,⋯,Xk​ be independent Boolean variables s.t. Pr⁡[Xi=1]≥ϵ\Pr[X_i=1]\ge\epsilonPr[Xi​=1]≥ϵ. Then

Pr⁡[∀i:Xi=0]<exp⁡(−kϵ)\Pr[\forall i:X_i=0]\lt\exp(-k\epsilon)Pr[∀i:Xi​=0]<exp(−kϵ)

By independence,

Pr⁡[∀i:Xi=0]=∏iPr⁡[Xi=0]<(1−ϵ)k≤exp⁡(−kϵ).\Pr[\forall i:X_i=0]=\prod_i\Pr[X_i=0]\lt(1-\epsilon)^k\le\exp(-k\epsilon).Pr[∀i:Xi​=0]=i∏​Pr[Xi​=0]<(1−ϵ)k≤exp(−kϵ).

(by 1+x≤exp⁡(x)1+x\le\exp(x)1+x≤exp(x))

Apply this to zero-sided and one-sided errors:

  • Define XiX_iXi​ to indicate whether trial iii gives the correct output.
  • Instead of having error probability 1/41/41/4, we actually assume that error probability for once is less than 1−1p(n)1-\frac{1}{p(n)}1−p(n)1​ and still achieve error probability exp⁡(−q(n))\exp(-q(n))exp(−q(n)) for all by running k=p(n)q(n)k=p(n)q(n)k=p(n)q(n) trials, which is polynomial number.

For two-sided error:

🤔Lemma 4 (Chernoff-Hoeffding Bound). Let XXX be the sum of kkk independent Boolean random variables. Assume μL≤E[X]≤μH\mu_L\le\mathbb E[X]\le\mu_HμL​≤E[X]≤μH​, t>0t>0t>0. Then

Pr⁡[X<μL−t]≤exp⁡(−2t2/k),Pr⁡[X>μH+t]≤exp⁡(−2t2/k).\Pr[X<\mu_L-t]\le\exp(-2t^2/k),\\\Pr[X>\mu_H+t]\le\exp(-2t^2/k).Pr[X<μL​−t]≤exp(−2t2/k),Pr[X>μH​+t]≤exp(−2t2/k).

We define the random indicator XiX_iXi​ to indicate whether trial iii gave correct output. We assume that Pr⁡[Xi=1]≥12+ϵ\Pr[X_i=1]\ge\frac{1}{2}+\epsilonPr[Xi​=1]≥21​+ϵ and kkk is odd. Let X=∑i=1kXiX=\sum_{i=1}^kX_iX=∑i=1k​Xi​, we have E[X]≥k2+kϵ\mathbb E[X]\ge\frac{k}{2}+k\epsilonE[X]≥2k​+kϵ. Applying Chernoff-Hoeffding bound, we have

Pr⁡[X<k2]=Pr⁡[X<μL−kϵ]≤exp⁡(−2(kϵ)2/k)=exp⁡(−2kϵ2)\Pr[X<\frac{k}{2}]=\Pr[X<\mu_L-k\epsilon]\le\exp(-2(k\epsilon)^2/k)\\=\exp(-2k\epsilon^2)Pr[X<2k​]=Pr[X<μL​−kϵ]≤exp(−2(kϵ)2/k)=exp(−2kϵ2)

using μL=k2+kϵ\mu_L=\frac{k}{2}+k\epsilonμL​=2k​+kϵ. Instead of have error probability 1/41/41/4, we assume error probability for once just less than 1/2−1/p(n)1/2-1/p(n)1/2−1/p(n) and achieve error probability exp⁡(−q(n))\exp(-q(n))exp(−q(n)) by running k=p(n)2q(n)2k=\frac{p(n)^2q(n)}{2}k=2p(n)2q(n)​ independent trials.

These analysis applies to both polynomial-time bounded and log-space bounded randomized complexity classes.

Polynomial Identity Testing

Don’t know:

  1. Whether randomized classes have complete problem;
  2. Any hierarchy results for randomized classes.

PIT

Polynomial Identity Testing (PIT): Testing whether a polynomial is identically zero.

PIT problem is efficiently solvable in randomized polynomial time but not known to be solvable deterministically in polynomial time.

📖Definition 21 (Arithmetic circuit). An arithmetic circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of the following:

  1. A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) where the in-degree of every node is either 000 or 222.
  2. A labeling ℓ\ellℓ for the nodes VVV.
  3. A choice of mmm outputs gates o1,⋯ ,om∈Vo_1,\cdots,o_m\in Vo1​,⋯,om​∈V.

Nodes VVV corresponds to gates, edges AAA corresponds to wires. Nodes of in-degree 000 are input gates. The labeling function satisfies ∀\forall∀ gates ggg:

  1. If fanin of ggg is 000, ℓ(g)∈{1,x1,⋯ ,xn}\ell(g)\in\{1,x_1,\cdots,x_n\}ℓ(g)∈{1,x1​,⋯,xn​}.
  2. If fanin of ggg is 222, ℓ(g)∈{+,×,−}\ell(g)\in\{+,\times,-\}ℓ(g)∈{+,×,−}.

故意不说人话……就是把多项式分解成多层二元运算。一个多项式就相当于只有一个输出口的算术电路。

Such an arithmetic circuit compute a polynomial p∈R[x1,⋯ ,xn]p\in R[x_1,\cdots,x_n]p∈R[x1​,⋯,xn​] for any Abelian ring RRR. 阿贝尔环

Usually we consider arithmetic circuits w.r.t. ring.

AFIT

aka Arithmetic formula identity testing

A variant of PIT: input polynomial is given by an arithmetic formula.

Instance: Arithmetic formula computing the polynomial P(x1,⋯ ,xn)∈Z[x1,⋯ ,xn]P(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\in\mathbb Z[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1​,⋯,xn​)∈Z[x1​,⋯,xn​].

Question: Is P(x)≡0P(x)\equiv0P(x)≡0?

A simple randomized algorithm: simply choose number a1,⋯ ,an∈{1,2,⋯ ,4m}a_1,\cdots,a_n\in\{1,2,\cdots,4m\}a1​,⋯,an​∈{1,2,⋯,4m} independently and uniformly at random, where mmm is the size of the given formula, evaluate P(a1,⋯ ,an)P(a_1,\cdots, a_n)P(a1​,⋯,an​) and answer accordingly.

Using Schwartz-Zippel lemma to analyze error probability.

🤔Lemma 5 (Schwartz-Zippel lemma). Let F\mathbb FF be a field, let P(x1,⋯ ,xn)∈F[x1,⋯ ,xn]P(x_1,\cdots, x_n)\in\mathbb F[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1​,⋯,xn​)∈F[x1​,⋯,xn​] be a non-zero polynomial of total degree at most ddd. Let S⊆FS\subseteq\mathbb FS⊆F, and pick a1,⋯ ,an∈Sa_1,\cdots, a_n\in Sa1​,⋯,an​∈S independently and uniformly at random. Then

Pr⁡[P(a1,⋯ ,an)=0]≤d∣S∣.\Pr[P(a_1,\cdots,a_n)=0]\le\frac{d}{|S|}.Pr[P(a1​,⋯,an​)=0]≤∣S∣d​.

Proof by induction on nnn.

So the error probability is decided by mmm, at most 1/41/41/4.

🎯Theorem 45. AFIT∈coRPAFIT\in coRPAFIT∈coRP.

没太懂这一部分

Sample from 1,⋯ ,m1,\cdots,m1,⋯,m is equivalent to sample kkk times from 1,⋯ ,2⌈log⁡2m⌉1,\cdots,2^{\lceil\log_2m\rceil}1,⋯,2⌈log2​m⌉. k=ω(log⁡n)k=\omega(\log n)k=ω(logn).

ACIT

aka arithmetic circuit identity testing

Instance: Arithmetic circuit computing the polynomial P(x1,⋯ ,xn)∈Z[x1,⋯ ,xn]P(x_1,\cdots,x_n)\in\mathbb Z[x_1,\cdots,x_n]P(x1​,⋯,xn​)∈Z[x1​,⋯,xn​].

Question: Is P(x)≡0P(x)\equiv0P(x)≡0?

Circuit of size mmm has at most mmm multiplication gates. The degree of the polynomial computed is at most 2m2^m2m. The same approach as in arithmetic formula calls for draw random number from 1,⋯ ,2m+21,\cdots,2^{m+2}1,⋯,2m+2. (exponential!)

To remedy this, we switch to modular arithmetic with randomly chosen prime modulus. Use prime number theorem to analyze error probability.

Let π(x)\pi(x)π(x) be the number of prime number less than xxx. By prime number theory,

π(x)∼xln⁡x.\pi(x)\sim\frac{x}{\ln x}.π(x)∼lnxx​.

🤔Lemma 6. For all m>1m>1m>1, we have π(2m)≥2mm\pi(2^m)\ge\frac{2^m}{m}π(2m)≥m2m​.

🤔🎯Theorem 35. ACIT∈coRPACIT\in coRPACIT∈coRP.

Det kan jeg ikke forstår

An Alternative Characterization of Time Bounded Classes

We have alternative characterization of BPPBPPBPP. Also there are similar alternatives of ZPPZPPZPP and RPRPRP.

Proposition 4. Let LLL be a language. Then L∈BPPL\in BPPL∈BPP iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L′∈PL'\in PL′∈P s.t. ∀x\forall x∀x:

x∈L⇒Pr⁡y∈{0,1}q(∣x∣)[⟨x,y⟩∈L′]≥34x∉L⇒Pr⁡y∈{0,1}q(∣x∣)[⟨x,y⟩∉L′]≥34x\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']\ge\frac{3}{4}\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\not\in L']\ge\frac{3}{4}x∈L⇒y∈{0,1}q(∣x∣)Pr​[⟨x,y⟩∈L′]≥43​x∈L⇒y∈{0,1}q(∣x∣)Pr​[⟨x,y⟩∈L′]≥43​

We say that the randomized computation uses q(∣x∣)q(|x|)q(∣x∣) random bits.

Using success amplification a randomized algorithm using RRR random bits and having error probability less than 1/41/41/4 can be transformed to a randomized algorithm using kRkRkR random bits and having error probability less than exp⁡(−k/8)\exp(-k/8)exp(−k/8) by running kkk trials and taking the majority vote.

Randomized Computation and the Polynomial-time Hierarchy

By definition, RP⊆NPRP\subseteq NPRP⊆NP.

But we don’t know whether BPP⊆NPBPP\subseteq NPBPP⊆NP or NP⊆BPPNP\subseteq BPPNP⊆BPP.

We just guess: BPP=PBPP=PBPP=P thus BPP⊆NPBPP\subseteq NPBPP⊆NP.

But we can prove that BPPBPPBPP is contained in the second level of polynomial-time hierarchy.

🎯Theorem 36. BPP⊆Σ2P∩Π2PBPP\subseteq \Sigma_2^P\cap\Pi_2^PBPP⊆Σ2P​∩Π2P​.

Prove that BPP⊆Σ2PBPP\subseteq\Sigma_2^PBPP⊆Σ2P​. From this also we get BPP⊆Π2PBPP\subseteq\Pi_2^PBPP⊆Π2P​.

  • Let L∈BPPL\in BPPL∈BPP. We have a polynomial q(n)q(n)q(n) and a language L′∈PL'\in PL′∈P s.t. for all xxx we have

    x∈L⇒Pr⁡y∈{0,1}q(∣x∣)[⟨x,y⟩∈L′]≥1−12q(∣x∣),x∉L⇒Pr⁡y∈{0,1}q(∣x∣)[⟨x,y⟩∈L′]<1−12q(∣x∣).x\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']\ge1-\frac{1}{2q(|x|)},\\x\not\in L\Rarr\Pr_{y\in\{0,1\}^{q(|x|)}}[\langle x,y\rangle\in L']<1-\frac{1}{2q(|x|)}.x∈L⇒y∈{0,1}q(∣x∣)Pr​[⟨x,y⟩∈L′]≥1−2q(∣x∣)1​,x∈L⇒y∈{0,1}q(∣x∣)Pr​[⟨x,y⟩∈L′]<1−2q(∣x∣)1​.

  • Let m=q(∣x∣)m=q(|x|)m=q(∣x∣). For given xxx, we define Sx={y∈{0,1}m∣⟨x,y⟩∈L′}S_x=\{y\in\{0,1\}^m|\langle x,y\rangle\in L'\}Sx​={y∈{0,1}m∣⟨x,y⟩∈L′}. Thus, for all xxx we have

    x∈L⇒∣Sx∣≥(1−12m)2m,x∉L⇒∣Sx∣<12m2m.x\in L\Rarr|S_x|\ge(1-\frac{1}{2m})2^m,\\x\not\in L\Rarr|S_x|<\frac{1}{2m}2^m.x∈L⇒∣Sx​∣≥(1−2m1​)2m,x∈L⇒∣Sx​∣<2m1​2m.

    Claim that x∈Lx\in Lx∈L iff

    ∃u1,⋯ ,um∈{0,1}m∀r∈{0,1}m:⋁i=1m⟨x,ui⊕r⟩∈L′,\exist u_1,\cdots, u_m\in\{0,1\}^m\forall r\in\{0,1\}^m:\\\bigvee_{i=1}^m\langle x,u_i\oplus r\rangle\in L',∃u1​,⋯,um​∈{0,1}m∀r∈{0,1}m:i=1⋁m​⟨x,ui​⊕r⟩∈L′,

    where ui⊕ru_i\oplus rui​⊕r denote the coordinate-wise exclusive-or. 什么是坐标或运算？

  • This shows that L∈Σ2PL\in\Sigma_2^PL∈Σ2P​ since this can be done in polynomial time.

It remains to prove the predicate is equivalent to ⋃i=1mui⊕Sx={0,1}m\bigcup_{i=1}^mu_i\oplus S_x=\{0,1\}^m⋃i=1m​ui​⊕Sx​={0,1}m.

Randomized Computation and Boolean Circuits

Everything that can be computed in polynomial-time by randomized algorithm can also be computed using Boolean circuits.

🎯Theorem 37. (Adleman’s Theorem). BPP⊆P/polyBPP\subseteq P/polyBPP⊆P/poly.

证明也不太懂

entry.title: 新坑预告——《安徒生童话》丹麦语原文精读
entry.content:
在童年的梦境中，我们曾徜徉于安徒生笔下的神奇世界。他的故事不仅构建了我们幼年的幻想，也深深触动了我们的内心。如今，当我重拾这些经典童话，并用丹麦语的原汁原味去品读，那份久违的感动再次涌上心头。透过丹麦语的细腻表达，我希望与你们分享那些在翻译中可能被忽略的细节与韵味，揭开每一个故事背后的语言魅力与文化底蕴。

开启新坑的目的

这个全新项目不仅是我对丹麦语学习热情的延续，也是对童年回忆的深情追溯。通过精读安徒生的经典童话，我希望在积累更多丹麦语单词和地道表达的同时，重温那些陪伴我们成长的故事。这不仅是语言学习的旅程，更是一次文化与情感的深度体验。

童年记忆中的经典

从《丑小鸭》的蜕变，到《卖火柴的小女孩》的动人心魄，这些故事早已成为我们共同的记忆。以下是我小学初中时在语文课堂上涉及到的童话故事：

  • 人教版小学语文
    • 二年级下册——《丑小鸭》Den grimme ælling
    • 六年级下册——《卖火柴的小女孩》Den lille Pige med Svovlstikkerne
  • 人教版初中语文
    • 七年级上册——《皇帝的新装》Kejserens nye klæder

精读形式与内容

每篇文章将包括对丹麦语原文的逐段解析，帮助我们更深入地理解安徒生的创作过程及其语言特征。这不仅是一次语言学习的旅程，更是一次文化与情感的深度体验。我相信，这个系列将带领大家进入一个绚丽的梦境，重新发现那些曾经赋予我们无限幻想的童话世界。

丹麦语原文资源

如果你也对原文感兴趣，可以在 这个网站 上找到相关的丹麦语资源。

参与&互动

诚挚邀请你们一同探讨这些令人心驰神往的故事，一起在丹麦语的世界中畅游。虽然我仍在学习丹麦语的过程中，难免有疏漏或错误的地方，但我欢迎大家提出宝贵意见，我将虚心接受并不断进步。

敬请关注即将开启的《安徒生童话》丹麦语原文精读系列，让我们一起在童话的海洋中重新起航，发现那些曾经种下的美好种子。

entry.title: Codeforces Round 957 (Div. 3) 解题思路
entry.content:
本次比赛 链接

现在的水平只能碰碰 Div 3

A. Only Pluses

三个数越相近，乘积就越大。因此五次递增每次分别作用于当前三个数中最小的那个。

B. Angry Monk

除了当前最长的那一个片段之外，其他片段都必须要掰成一节节之后再拼上。这样总步数最小。

C. Gorilla and Permutation

定义的两个函数 f(i)f(i)f(i) 表示数组前缀长度 iii 中所有大于 kkk 的数字之和，g(i)g(i)g(i) 表示数组前缀长度 iii 中所有小于 mmm 的数字之和。要想最大化 ∑i(f(i)−g(i))\sum_i(f(i)-g(i))∑i​(f(i)−g(i)), 就必须要让 f(i)f(i)f(i) 尽量大，g(i)g(i)g(i) 尽量小。

所以构造的排列就是先是比 kkk 大的数字降序排列，中间的无所谓，之后是比 mmm 小的数字的升序排列。

D. Test of Love

题目大意

给出一个长度为 nnn 的序列，其中包含水 W、鳄鱼 C 和浮木 L。如果在岸上或在浮木上，可以向前最多跳 m 格，可以跳到水里、浮木或岸上；如果当前在水里，则可以向前游一格，但整个过程中最多能游 k 格；无论如何都不能进入鳄鱼所在的格子。问：是否从起始位置到达彼岸。

解题思路

暴搜。因为游是有限制的，跳是无限制的，所以能跳则跳。

  • 如果当前在岸上或在浮木上，向前搜索选择跳到最远的浮木。如果前面 m 格都没有浮木，选择能跳到最远的水里。
  • 如果当前在水里，向前游一格。
  • 如果游到鳄鱼格，则搜索失败。
  • 如果游到或跳到彼岸，则搜索成功。

参考代码

E. Novice’s Mistake

题目大意

给定 nnn，求所有的 (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) 对，满足 a×n−ba\times n-ba×n−b 的结果对应的（非空）字符串刚好和将 nnn 对应字符串复制并拼接 aaa 次，然后裁剪掉长度为 bbb 的后缀得到的字符串一样。

解题思路

a,ba,ba,b 的范围 10510^5105，因此不能用最直观的暴力 O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) 解法。

注意到 a×na\times na×n 的范围，最多不会超过 n×104n\times 10^4n×104。又根据“字符串复制拼接”操作，得出 a×n−ba\times n-ba×n−b 对应结果只有那么几种。比如 n=34n=34n=34 时，a×n−ba\times n-ba×n−b 可能取值只有 3,34,343,3434,34343,3434343,34,343,3434,34343,3434343,34,343,3434,34343,343434。针对这些值再暴力枚举 aaa 即可。此方法的时间复杂度为 O(nlog⁡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn)。

参考代码

F. Valuable Cards

题目大意

给定一个数组和一个值 xxx。目标是将数组划分成最少的段数，使得每段中都不存在任何一个子集，其中所有元素的积为 xxx。

解题思路

贪心。一段一段地找，只要发现有几个元素相乘等于 xxx，就立马切开。具体实现可以使用 C++ STL 里高效的 set 来存储所有 xxx 除以一些元素的商，一旦新扫描的值匹配上了，就立刻切开。

参考代码

G. Ultra-Meow

题目大意

定义 MEX(a,b)MEX(a,b)MEX(a,b) 函数表示 aaa 集合中未出现的第 kkk 个正整数。求 {1,⋯ ,n}\{1,\cdots,n\}{1,⋯,n} 的所有子集 bbb 的 MEXMEXMEX 值之和 ∑b⊆aMEX(b,∣b∣+1)\sum_{b\subseteq a}MEX(b,|b|+1)∑b⊆a​MEX(b,∣b∣+1).

解题思路

对于 nnn，MEXMEXMEX 函数的取值范围是 111 到 2n+12n+12n+1。对于每个 MEXMEXMEX 函数值，从 000 到 nnn 枚举子集的大小 sizesizesize。

对于 MEXMEXMEX 值为 valvalval, 子集大小为 sizesizesize 而言，

  • 1,⋯ ,val−11,\cdots,val-11,⋯,val−1 位置上必须刚好有 sizesizesize 个位置不在子集里。那么刚好有 a=(val−1)−sizea=(val-1)-sizea=(val−1)−size 个位置上的值在子集里。

    （如果 valvalval 比 nnn 大，val−1val-1val−1 被进一步限制为 nnn）

    情况的可能性有 (min⁡{val−1,n}a)\left(\begin{array}{cc}\min\{val-1,n\}\\a\end{array}\right)(min{val−1,n}a​) 种。

  • 如果 valvalval 比 nnn 小，那么 val+1,⋯ ,nval+1,\cdots,nval+1,⋯,n 位置上就刚好有 size−asize-asize−a 个位置上的值在子集里。该情况的可能性有 (n−valsize−a)\left(\begin{array}{cc}n-val\\size-a\end{array}\right)(n−valsize−a​) 种。

因此，MEXMEXMEX 值为 valvalval，子集大小为 sizesizesize 对应的子集个数为：

(min⁡{val−1,n}a)×(max⁡{0,n−val}size−a)\left(\begin{array}{cc}\min\{val-1,n\}\\a\end{array}\right)\times\left(\begin{array}{cc}\max\{0,n-val\}\\size-a\end{array}\right)(min{val−1,n}a​)×(max{0,n−val}size−a​)

最终的结果就是对应的 MEXMEXMEX 与之相乘再求和。

参考代码

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 5 The Polynomoial-Time Hierarchy
entry.content:
Idea: arithmetic hierarchy from recursion theory.

Halting problem HALTHALTHALT is a recursive enumerable language that is undecidable.

The polynomial-time hierarchy considers polynomial time and SATSATSAT instead of HALTHALTHALT.

Oracle Turing Machines

An oracle Turing machine M?M^?M? is equipped with an additional tape, the query tape, and has three new special states qask,qyes,qnoq_{ask},q_{yes},q_{no}qask​,qyes​,qno​. The query tape is a write-only tape.

The operation of M?M^?M? is defined relative to an oracle language AAA.

Denote M?M^?M? together with oracle language AAA by MAM^AMA.

Whenever MAM^AMA enters the state qaskq_{ask}qask​:

  • Let zzz be the string of symbols written to the query tape. The query tape is reinitialized to a black tape.
  • If z∈Az\in Az∈A, computation resumes in the state qyesq_{yes}qyes​.
  • If z∉Az\not\in Az∈A, computation resumes in the state qnoq_{no}qno​.

Define timeMA(x)time_{M^A}(x)timeMA​(x) and spaceMA(x)space_{M^A}(x)spaceMA​(x) for an oracle Turing machine with an oracle language AAA to be the number of computation steps and number of cells of work tape used during computation on input xxx. The same way we define time-bounded and space-bounded oracle Turing machines.

Then we need to define oracle versions of complexity classes. Straightforward to define time-bounded complexity classes, but be careful to define space-bounded complexity classes.

DTIMEA(T(n)),DSPACEA(S(n)),NTIMEA(T(n))DTIME^A(T(n)),DSPACE^A(S(n)),NTIME^A(T(n))DTIMEA(T(n)),DSPACEA(S(n)),NTIMEA(T(n)).

❗Problem for non-deterministic space-bounded oracle Turing machine: it may write very long strings to the oracle tape.

Solution: Requiring the oracle Turing machine to behave deterministically in the time between writing the first symbol to the oracle tape and making the oracle query. (deterministic oracle access)

Thus we define NSPACEA(S(n))NSPACE^A(S(n))NSPACEA(S(n)) as the class of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded non-deterministic oracle Turing machine with deterministic oracle access to oracle AAA.

The definition can be extended to other complexity classes.

PAP^APA and NPANP^ANPA for any oracle language AAA.

The oracle may be chosen from some class of languages. Let C\mathcal CC be a class of languages.

DTIMEC(T(n))=⋃A∈CDTIMEA(T(n))DTIME^\mathcal C(T(n))=\bigcup_{A\in\mathcal C}DTIME^A(T(n))DTIMEC(T(n))=A∈C⋃​DTIMEA(T(n))

Similarly we have DSPACEC(T(n))DSPACE^\mathcal C(T(n))DSPACEC(T(n)), NTIMEC(T(n))NTIME^\mathcal C(T(n))NTIMEC(T(n)) and NSPACEC(T(n))NSPACE^\mathcal C(T(n))NSPACEC(T(n)).

This again extends to all other complexity classes such as PNPP^{NP}PNP.

Turing Reductions

📖Definition 17 (Turing reductions). Let L1L_1L1​ and L2L_2L2​ be languages. We say that L1L_1L1​ log-space Turing machine reduces to L2L_2L2​ (L1≤Tlog⁡L2L_1\le_T^{\log}L_2L1​≤Tlog​L2​), if L1∈LL2L_1\in L^{L_2}L1​∈LL2​. Similarly we say L1L_1L1​ polynomial time Turing reduces to L2L_2L2​ (L1≤TPL2L_1\le_T^PL_2L1​≤TP​L2​), if L1∈PL2L_1\in P^{L_2}L1​∈PL2​.

It also satisfies transitivity.

🤔Lemma 2. Transitivity.

  • L1≤Tlog⁡L2,L2≤Tlog⁡L3⇒L1≤Tlog⁡L3L_1\le_T^{\log}L_2,L_2\le_T^{\log}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_T^{\log}L_3L1​≤Tlog​L2​,L2​≤Tlog​L3​⇒L1​≤Tlog​L3​
  • L1≤TPL2,L2≤TPL3⇒L1≤TPL3L_1\le_T^{P}L_2,L_2\le_T^{P}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_T^{P}L_3L1​≤TP​L2​,L2​≤TP​L3​⇒L1​≤TP​L3​

🤔Proposition 3. The class L,NL,P,PSPACE,EXPL,NL,P,PSPACE,EXPL,NL,P,PSPACE,EXP are all closed under log-space Turing reductions. The class P,PSPACE,EXPP,PSPACE,EXPP,PSPACE,EXP are all closed under polynomial-time Turing machine.

The Polynomial-time Hierarchy via Oracles and Quantifiers

For a class of language C\mathcal CC, denote coCco\mathcal CcoC the class of complements of languages of C\mathcal CC.

coC={L‾∣L∈C}co\mathcal C=\{\overline L|L\in\mathcal C\}coC={L∣L∈C}

📖Definition 18 (polynomial-time hierarchy). Let Δ0P=Σ0P=Π0P=P\Delta_0^P=\Sigma_0^P=\Pi_0^P=PΔ0P​=Σ0P​=Π0P​=P. For i≥0i\ge0i≥0, define further Δi+1P=PΣiP\Delta_{i+1}^P=P^{\Sigma_i^P}Δi+1P​=PΣiP​, Σi+1P=NPΣiP\Sigma_{i+1}^P=NP^{\Sigma_i^P}Σi+1P​=NPΣiP​ and Πi+1P=coNPΣiP\Pi_{i+1}^P=coNP^{\Sigma_i^P}Πi+1P​=coNPΣiP​. Finally, let Polynomial Hierarchy PH=⋃i≥0ΣiPPH=\bigcup_{i\ge0}\Sigma_i^PPH=⋃i≥0​ΣiP​.

The classes ΔiP,ΣiP,ΠiP\Delta_i^P,\Sigma_i^P,\Pi_i^PΔiP​,ΣiP​,ΠiP​ are said to make up level iii of the polynomial-time hierarchy, and PHPHPH denotes the entire polynomial-time hierarchy.

Note that Δ1P=PP=P\Delta_1^P=P^P=PΔ1P​=PP=P, Σ1P=NPP=NP\Sigma_1^P=NP^P=NPΣ1P​=NPP=NP, Π1P=coNPP=coNP\Pi_1^P=coNP^P=coNPΠ1P​=coNPP=coNP.

On second level, we have PNP,NPNP,coNPNPP^{NP}, NP^{NP}, coNP^{NP}PNP,NPNP,coNPNP, continuing ad infimum.

Straightforward:

ΔiP⊆ΣiP∩ΠiP⊆ΣiP∪ΠiP⊆Δi+1P\Delta_i^P\subseteq\Sigma_i^P\cap\Pi_i^P\subseteq\Sigma_i^P\cup\Pi_i^P\subseteq\Delta_{i+1}^PΔiP​⊆ΣiP​∩ΠiP​⊆ΣiP​∪ΠiP​⊆Δi+1P​

🎯Theorem 27. PH⊆PSPACEPH\subseteq PSPACEPH⊆PSPACE.

Using polynomial space simply simulate the non-deterministic Turing machine same way as in proof of Theorem 10.

Then prove an equivalent definition of the classes ΣiP\Sigma_i^PΣiP​ and ΠiP\Pi_i^PΠiP​ in terms of quantifiers.

🎯Theorem 28. Let LLL be any language and let i≥1i\ge1i≥1. Then L∈ΣiPL\in\Sigma_i^PL∈ΣiP​ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L′∈Πi−1PL'\in\Pi_{i-1}^PL′∈Πi−1P​ s.t.

\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\exist y:|y|\le q(|x|)\and\langle x,y\rangle\in L'].

看不懂了。

🤔Corollary 3. Let LLL be any language and let i≥1i\ge1i≥1. Then L∈ΠiPL\in\Pi_i^PL∈ΠiP​ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L′∈Σi−1PL'\in\Sigma_{i-1}^PL′∈Σi−1P​ s.t.

∀x:[x∈L⇔∀y:∣y∣≤q(∣x∣)⇒⟨x,y⟩∈L′].\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\forall y:|y|\le q(|x|)\Rarr\langle x,y\rangle\in L'].∀x:[x∈L⇔∀y:∣y∣≤q(∣x∣)⇒⟨x,y⟩∈L′].

🤔Corollary 4. Let LLL be any language and let i≥1i\ge1i≥1. Then L∈ΣiPL\in\Sigma_i^PL∈ΣiP​ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L′∈PL'\in PL′∈P s.t.

∀x:[x∈L⇔∃qy1∀qy2⋯Qiqyi:⟨x,y1,y2,⋯ ,yi⟩∈L′],\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\exist^qy_1\forall^qy_2\cdots Q_i^qy_i:\langle x,y_1,y_2,\cdots,y_i\rangle\in L'],∀x:[x∈L⇔∃qy1​∀qy2​⋯Qiq​yi​:⟨x,y1​,y2​,⋯,yi​⟩∈L′],

where QiQ_iQi​ is ∃\exist∃ if iii is odd, and ∀\forall∀ if iii is even. Likewise, L∈ΠiPL\in\Pi_i^PL∈ΠiP​ iff there is a polynomial qqq and another language L′∈PL'\in PL′∈P s.t.

∀x:[x∈L⇔∀qy1∃qy2⋯Qiqyi:⟨x,y1,y2,⋯ ,yi⟩∈L′],\forall x:[x\in L\Lrarr\forall^qy_1\exist^qy_2\cdots Q_i^qy_i:\langle x,y_1,y_2,\cdots,y_i\rangle\in L'],∀x:[x∈L⇔∀qy1​∃qy2​⋯Qiq​yi​:⟨x,y1​,y2​,⋯,yi​⟩∈L′],

where QiQ_iQi​ is ∃\exist∃ if iii is even, and ∀\forall∀ if iii is odd.

Generalize whether P=NP,NP=coNPP=NP,NP=coNPP=NP,NP=coNP to question whether ΔiP=ΣiP,ΣiP=ΠiP\Delta_i^P=\Sigma_i^P,\Sigma_i^P=\Pi_i^PΔiP​=ΣiP​,ΣiP​=ΠiP​ for i>1i\gt1i>1.

🎯Theorem 29. If ΣiP=ΠiP\Sigma_i^P=\Pi_i^PΣiP​=ΠiP​ for some i≥1i\ge1i≥1 then PH=ΣiPPH=\Sigma_i^PPH=ΣiP​.

继续看 天书。

Completeness in the Polynomial-time Hierarchy

ΣiSAT\Sigma_iSATΣi​SAT Problem

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variables ψ=∃x1∀x2⋯Qixiφ(x1,⋯ ,xi)\psi=\exist x_1\forall x_2\cdots Q_ix_i\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_i)ψ=∃x1​∀x2​⋯Qi​xi​φ(x1​,⋯,xi​), where xj∈{0,1}njx_j\in\{0,1\}^{n_j}xj​∈{0,1}nj​ for all jjj and Qi=∀Q_i=\forallQi​=∀ for even iii and ∃\exist∃ for odd iii.

Question: Is ψ\psiψ true?

ΠiSAT\Pi_iSATΠi​SAT Problem

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variables ψ=∀x1∃x2⋯Qixiφ(x1,⋯ ,xi)\psi=\forall x_1\exist x_2\cdots Q_ix_i\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_i)ψ=∀x1​∃x2​⋯Qi​xi​φ(x1​,⋯,xi​), where xj∈{0,1}njx_j\in\{0,1\}^{n_j}xj​∈{0,1}nj​ for all jjj and Qi=∀Q_i=\forallQi​=∀ for odd iii and ∃\exist∃ for even iii.

Question: Is ψ\psiψ true?

🎯Theorem 30. ΣiSAT\Sigma_iSATΣi​SAT is complete for ΣiP\Sigma_i^PΣiP​ and ΠiSAT\Pi_iSATΠi​SAT is complete for ΠiP\Pi_i^PΠiP​.

前面的推论 4 都没懂……这个证明就更不懂了

In case of Qi=∃Q_i=\existQi​=∃, we ended up with a CNF formula φ\varphiφ.

In case of Qi=∀Q_i=\forallQi​=∀, we ended up with a DNF formula φ\varphiφ.

🎯Theorem 31. If PHPHPH has a complete language, then PHPHPH collapses.

This follows since PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE has complete problems.

Collapses 在此处指多项式层次结构中某一层以上的所有级别都重合的情况。

The Karp-Lipton Theorem

A possible way to prove P≠NPP\neq NPP=NP would be to show that there is some language in NPNPNP that is not computed by a family of polynomial size Boolean circuits, i.e., that NP⊈P/polyNP\not\subseteq P/polyNP⊆P/poly.

This is stronger than P≠NPP\neq NPP=NP since P⊆P/polyP\subseteq P/polyP⊆P/poly. It turns out that it is not stronger than the assumption that the polynomial-time hierarchy does not collapse.

🎯Theorem 32. Suppose that NP⊆P/polyNP\subseteq P/polyNP⊆P/poly. Then PH=Σ2P∩Π2PPH=\Sigma_2^P\cap\Pi_2^PPH=Σ2P​∩Π2P​.

Proof by Theorem 29, Corollary 4.

继续看不懂……
entry.summary:
Idea: arithmetic hierarchy from recursion theory.

Halting problem

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 4 Reductions and Completeness
entry.content:
Reductions

NP-completeness: by polynomial-time many-one reductions (aka Karp reductions)

Studying completeness of P and NL: by log-space many-one reduction. Also too powerful for completeness inside L.

📖Definition 14 (Log-space reductions). Let L1⊆Σ1∗L_1\subseteq\Sigma_1^*L1​⊆Σ1∗​ and L2⊆Σ2∗L_2\subseteq\Sigma_2^*L2​⊆Σ2∗​ be languages. A log-space many-one reduction from L1L_1L1​ to L2L_2L2​ is a function f:Σ1∗→Σ2∗f:\Sigma_1^*\rarr\Sigma_2^*f:Σ1∗​→Σ2∗​ s.t.

  1. There exists a log-space Turing machine computing fff.
  2. For all x∈Σ1∗x\in\Sigma_1^*x∈Σ1∗​, we have x∈L1⇔f(x)∈L2x\in L_1\Lrarr f(x)\in L_2x∈L1​⇔f(x)∈L2​.

Denote: L1≤mlog⁡L2L_1\le_m^{\log}L_2L1​≤mlog​L2​

The definition of polynomial-time many-one reduction (L1≤mpL2L_1\le_m^pL_2L1​≤mp​L2​) is similar (simply using polynomial-time Turing machine instead).

📖Definition 15 (≤mlog⁡\le_m^{\log}≤mlog​-hard/complete). Let LLL be a language and C\mathcal CC be a class of languages. We say that LLL is ≤mlog⁡\le_m^{\log}≤mlog​-hard for C\mathcal CC if for every L′∈CL'\in\mathcal CL′∈C we have L′≤mlog⁡LL'\le_m^{\log}LL′≤mlog​L. We say LLL is ≤mlog⁡\le_m^{\log}≤mlog​-complete if we additionally have L∈CL\in\mathcal CL∈C.

Reduction has property of transitivity.

🤔Lemma 1. L1≤mlog⁡L2,L2≤mlog⁡L3⇒L1≤mlog⁡L3L_1\le_m^{\log}L_2, L_2\le_m^{\log}L_3\Rarr L_1\le_m^{\log}L_3L1​≤mlog​L2​,L2​≤mlog​L3​⇒L1​≤mlog​L3​.

Let M1M_1M1​ and M2M_2M2​ be log-space Turing machines computing f1:L1→L2,f2:L2→L3f_1:L_1\to L_2,f_2:L_2\to L_3f1​:L1​→L2​,f2​:L2​→L3​, respectively. It suffices to show that f=f2∘f1f=f_2\circ f_1f=f2​∘f1​ is computable by log-space Turing machine MMM.

On input xxx, we simulate M2M_2M2​ with virtual input tape f1(x)f_1(x)f1​(x). We maintain a counter giving the position of the virtual input tape head of M2M_2M2​. To simulate step of computation of M2M_2M2​, we start simulating M1M_1M1​ on input xxx, counting and then discarding the output symbols by M1M_1M1​ until the output symbol where the virtual input tape head is placed is to be written. Then the step of M2M_2M2​ can be complete.

Let xxx be of length n=∣n∣n=|n|n=∣n∣. ∣f(x)∣=2O(log⁡n)=nO(1)|f(x)|=2^{O(\log n)}=n^{O(1)}∣f(x)∣=2O(logn)=nO(1), storing the position of the virtual tape head as well as the work tapes of M1M_1M1​ and M2M_2M2​ takes space O(log⁡n)O(\log n)O(logn).

我觉得也挺显然的呀，用两台对数空间的图灵机模拟，总空间仍然是对数的。

Then we define reduction ⪯\preceq⪯ between languages.

📖Definition 16. A language LLL is hard for C\mathcal CC under ⪯\preceq⪯ reductions if for all L′∈CL'\in\mathcal CL′∈C we have L′⪯LL'\preceq LL′⪯L. A language LLL is complete for C\mathcal CC under ⪯\preceq⪯ reductions if L∈CL\in\mathcal CL∈C in addition to begin hard for C\mathcal CC under ⪯\preceq⪯ reductions.

Complexity class has an important property: the complexity class is closed under reductions.

We say C\mathcal CC is closed w.r.t. ⪯\preceq⪯ reductions, if whenever L′⪯LL'\preceq LL′⪯L and L∈CL\in\mathcal CL∈C, we also have L′∈CL'\in CL′∈C. Proof omitted.

🤔Proposition 2. The classes L,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPL,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPL,NL,P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXP are all closed under log-space many-one reductions. The classes P,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPP,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXPP,NP,PSPACE,EXP,NEXP are all closed under polynomial-time many-one reductions.

NL-completeness

The basic NL-complete problem is given by connectivity in a directed graph (STCONSTCONSTCON).

STCON

The instance: Directed graph DDD and nodes sss and ttt.

Question: Is there a directed path in DDD from sss to ttt?

🎯Theorem 20. STCONSTCONSTCON is complete for NL.

A non-deterministic log-space Turing machine can guess a path from sss to ttt one node at a time, reusing space.

To show NL-hardness, Let L∈NLL\in NLL∈NL be accepted by non-deterministic log-space Turing machine MMM.

Given input xxx s.t. MMM accepts xxx iff there is a path in the configuration graph of MMM on input xxx from the initial configuration to an accepting configuration.

A log-space reduction from LLL to STCONSTCONSTCON is:

On input xxx we generate all configurations of MMM on input xxx, which then forms the set of nodes together with an additional node ttt. Initial configuration becomes the node sss.

Next generate all arcs between configurations corresponding to a single step of the Turing machine and finally arcs between all accepting configurations to the new node ttt. We then have that the resulting directed graph DDD has a path from sss to ttt iff MMM accepts xxx.

By Savitch’s Theorem and Immerman-Szelepcsényi Theorem, STCON∈DSPACE(log⁡2n)STCON\in DSPACE(\log^2n)STCON∈DSPACE(log2n) and STCON‾∈NL\overline{STCON}\in NLSTCON∈NL, respectively.

P/NP-completeness

Basic PPP and NPNPNP-complete problems are given by the ability of Boolean circuits to simulate Turing machines on fixed input length. For PPP this gives the circuit value problem.

CVP problem

Instance: Boolean circuit CCC on nnn inputs and input x∈{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx∈{0,1}n.

Question: Is C(x)=1C(x)=1C(x)=1?

🎯Theorem 21. CVPCVPCVP is complete for PPP.

SAT problem

CircuitSAT

Instance: Boolean circuit CCC on nnn inputs

Question: Does there exist x∈{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx∈{0,1}n s.t. C(x)=1C(x)=1C(x)=1?

🎯Theorem 22. CircuitSATCircuitSATCircuitSAT is complete for NPNPNP.

Let me use Chinese

为什么 CircuitSAT 属于 NPNPNP。简单理解就是非确定性图灵机 NTM 可以在多项式时间解决此问题。一个简单的思想就是暴力枚举，一共遍历 2n2^n2n 次。这样在确定性图灵机 DTM 上确实就是 O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n)，但是在非确定性图灵机上，就厉害了。针对每一位，非确定性图灵机可以同时猜测 000 和 111，这样一共遍历 nnn 次分别对应 nnn 位，就得到了 NPNPNP 的结果。

As for NPNPNP-hard, construct language L∈NTIME(nk)L\in NTIME(n^k)L∈NTIME(nk) for k>0k\gt0k>0.

…

SAT

Instance: CNF formula φ\varphiφ.

Question: Does φ\varphiφ have a satisfying assigment?

🎯Theorem 23. CNF satisfiability problem is also complete for NPNPNP.

It’s easy to see SAT∈NPSAT\in NPSAT∈NP.

For hardness, by reduction from CircuitSATCircuitSATCircuitSAT.

Given a Boolean circuit CCC, take Tseitin transformation of CCC giving an equi-satisfiable CNF formula φ\varphiφ.

This involves introducing new variable for each gate of CCC.

The number of new variable for each gate is a constant.

3SAT 也是 NP 的，即每个合取范式最多包含三个子句。

PSPACE-completeness

Basic PSPACE-completeness is given by the problem of deciding validity of true quantified Boolean formulas as shown by Stockmeyer and Meyer. (TQBFTQBFTQBF)

Instance: Quantified Boolean formula with no free variable ψ=Q1x1Q2x2⋯Qnxnφ(x1,⋯ ,xn)\psi=Q_1x_1Q_2x_2\cdots Q_nx_n\varphi(x_1,\cdots,x_n)ψ=Q1​x1​Q2​x2​⋯Qn​xn​φ(x1​,⋯,xn​), where Qi∈{∀,∃}Q_i\in\{\forall,\exist\}Qi​∈{∀,∃} and xi∈{0,1}x_i\in\{0,1\}xi​∈{0,1} for all iii.

Question: Is ψ\psiψ true?

🎯Theorem 24. TQBFTQBFTQBF is complete for PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE.

To see TQBF∈PSPACETQBF\in PSPACETQBF∈PSPACE: The algorithm is a recursion. At the bottom of the recursion, if Qi=∀Q_i=\forallQi​=∀, return 111 iff both returned 111; if Qi=∃Q_i=\existQi​=∃, return 000 iff both returned 000. We of course need a stack with length O(n)O(n)O(n) for evaluating φ\varphiφ.

To show hardness, proof similar to Savitch’s theorem.

…

EXP/NEXP-completeness

Consider so-called succinct versions of complete problems of PPP and NPNPNP.

Let CCC be a Boolean circuit with nnn input gates and one output gate. The truthtable of CCC is the string tt(C)∈{0,1}2ntt(C)\in\{0,1\}^{2^n}tt(C)∈{0,1}2n giving the evaluation of CCC on all possible inputs.

Consider a language L⊆{0,1}∗L\subseteq\{0,1\}^*L⊆{0,1}∗. Then define the succinct version SuccinctLSuccinctLSuccinctL of LLL simply by SuccinctL={C∣tt(C)∈L}SuccinctL=\{C|tt(C)\in L\}SuccinctL={C∣tt(C)∈L}. Note that when L∈PL\in PL∈P we have that SuccinctL∈EXPSuccinctL\in EXPSuccinctL∈EXP simply by decompressing the input CCC to tt(C)tt(C)tt(C) in exponential time and then using the polynomial-time Turing machine to check for membership in LLL.

简而言之，把上面这些玩意的真值表算出来，就是属于 EXP/NEXP 的复杂度类。

Similarly we have SuccinctL∈NEXPSuccinctL\in NEXPSuccinctL∈NEXP when L∈NPL\in NPL∈NP.

🎯Theorem 25. SuccinctCVPSuccinctCVPSuccinctCVP is complete for EXPEXPEXP.

Similar transformation.

🎯Theorem 26. SucinctCircuitSATSucinctCircuitSATSucinctCircuitSAT and SuccinctSATSuccinctSATSuccinctSAT are complete for NEXPNEXPNEXP.
entry.summary:
Reductions

NP-completeness: by polynomial-time many-one red

entry.title: 德语学习 B2 Kapitel 6 Fit für ...
entry.content:
Inhalt

  1. Fit für den Onlineeinkauf
  2. Fit am Telefon
  3. Fit für die Kollegen
  4. Fit für die Prüfung

6-1 Fit für … (1)

fit für Akkusativ 适合某事，胜任某事

Kurios 奇特的，奇怪的

6-2 Fit für … (2)

der Quark 凝乳

das Eisen-/ 铁

Edelmetal 贵金属

die Analogie-n 类比，类推

die Denksportaufgabe-n 脑筋急转弯

6-3 Fit für den Onlineeinkauf (1)

Was kaufen Sie in Geschäften? Was kaufen Sie im Internet?

In Geschäften: Lebensmittel, Arzneimittel, Brillen

Im Internet: Elektronische Geräte, Kleidung, Onlinekurs, Spielwaren, Tickets, Reise

der Konsument-en 消费者

das Benutzerkonto-ten 用户账号

das Virenschutzprogramm 杀软，病毒防护软件

der Rechnungsbetrag-"e 发票金额

die/der Firewall-s 防火墙

der Datenschutz-/ 数据保护

die Verschlüsselung-en 加密

die Kontodaten Pl 账户资料

der Doppelklick-s 双击

das Onlinebanking-/ 网银

die Webseite-n 网页

die Suchmaschine-n 搜索引擎

der Virus-ren 病毒

die Startseite-n 首页

das Passwort-"er 密码

der Kreditkartenbetrug-"e 信用卡欺诈

die Reklamation-en 索赔，理赔

der Mindestbestellwert-e 最低订购额

6-4 Fit für den Onlineeinkauf (2)

recht 很，相当 adv

im Trend liegen = populär 流行的，时髦的

zufolge + Dativ 根据，按照，依据

der Internetnutzer- 互联网用户

die Dienstleistung-en 服务，服务工作

der Interneteinkauf-/ 网购 = das Onlineshopping

beachten 留意，注意，当心

Verbraucherzentrale Hamburg 汉堡消费者保护中心

die Art-/ 方式，方法，风格

hochfahren 启动 可分v

sich(Dativ) um/über etwas Gedanken machen 考虑某事

sich anstellen 排队等候

die Auswahl-/ 选择

riesig 巨大的 adj

verlockend 诱人的，吸引人的

verlocken 引诱，诱惑 v

der Haken- 钩子；潜在的困难

einen Haken haben = Was ist falsch dabei?

die Versandkost-en 运费

der Mindestbestellwert-e 最小订单额

6-5 Fit für den Onlineeinkauf (3)

der Umtausch-/ 退换，调换

der Widerruf-e 撤销

das Warenpaket-e 产品包装

das Widerrufsformular-e 撤销表格

jmdm etwas zur Verfügung stellen 将某物供某人支配

die Rücksendung-en 退货，退回

beilegen 加进，附入

wirksam 有作用的，有效果的

6-6 Fit für den Onlineeinkauf (4)

um … besorgt sein 为某人/某事担心

es nicht so genau mit etwas nehmen = nicht sorgfältig sein 不谨慎

berechtigt 有根据的，合理的

stöbern 翻腾，翻寻

ein Benutzerkonto anlegen 创建账号

die Angabe-n 陈述，说明

die Anschrift-en 通讯地址

unumgänglich 必然的，不可避免的

angeben 陈述，说明，告知 可分v

notwendig 必要的，必需的

zwingend 强制的，强迫的

übertragen 转抄，转播，改编 可分v

abfangen 拦住，截获

verschlüsseln 加密

der Schloss-"er 锁

die Statusleiste-n 状态栏

der Browser-s 浏览器

der Bezahlvorgang-"e 支付流程

die Zahlungsmöglichkeit-en 付款方式

gängig 通用的

gegen Rechnung 凭借账单

der Versand-/ 发货

die Vorkasse-/ 预付

die Nachnahme-n 到付

begleichen 结清

der Kaufbetrag-"e = der Rechnungsbetrag 消费金额

der Paketdienst-e 包裹邮递服务

das E-Payment-Verfahren 电子支付

sich durchsetzen 得以贯彻，获得承认

der Zahlungsanbieter- 支付服务供应商

veranlassen 安排

die Sofort-Überweisung 即时转账

6-7 Fit für den Onlineeinkauf (5)

böse Überraschung = unangenehmes Ereignis 不愉快的经历

unverzichtbar 不可缺少的，不能放弃的

der/die Firewall-s 防火墙

mit einer Firewall ausgestattet sein 配置一个防火墙

der Türsteher- 守门人

der Datenverkehr-/ 数据传输

die Kombination-en 组合

vielmehr 确切地说，不如说

das Sonderzeichen- 特殊符号

wahllos 任意的，不按顺序的

zudem 此外，再者，而且

verwenden 应用，使用

6-8 Passiv 过程被动态和状态被动态

werden + 过去分词，表示过程被动。比如：这个商品正在被打包。

sein + 过去分词，表示状态/结果被动。比如：这个商品已经被打包好了。

Seite 103 的 题 3c 太难了

6-9 Fit an Telefon (1)

Warum fühlen sich Telefonanrufe unangenehm an?

Sorge, sich nicht korrekt ausdrücken zu können, dass Wörter fehlen, dass man den Ton nicht trifft, dass man den anderen nicht versteht.

6-10 Fit an Telefon (2)

sich erkundigen 询问，了解

das Schreiben- 公文，书信，函件

die Computeranlage-n 计算机设备

erneuern 更新，更换

ausführlich 详细的，详尽的

bezüglich 关于 + 第二格

die Installation-en 安装

die Betreuung-en 维护，管理；看管

der Typ-en 小子，家伙，崽儿，小弟娃（含有轻视的意味）

vorbeikommen 【口】顺道过来 可分

durchgeben 传达，通知

dazwischenkommen 意外发生 可分v

auflegen 挂电话 可分v

Dialog 1 Negativ:

  • unhöflich
  • klingt, als wäre das Telefonat eine unangenehme Aufgabe
  • Fenster offen und viel Lärm
  • Unterbricht Telefonat, spricht mit jemand anderem, konzentriert sich nicht auf das Telefonat
  • ist nicht gut vorbereitet: weiß nicht genau, was er will, hat keinen Stift
  • verhält sich nicht zuvorkommend: gibt die Adresse nicht direkt durch, sondern verweist auf die Internetseite, nennt am Ende seinen Namen nicht noch mal
  • unhöflich, geht nicht auf mögliche Bedürfnisse des anderen ein
  • wirkt uninteressiert am Zustandekommen des Treffens, fragt bei Namen und Telefonnummer nicht noch mal nach, dass er verstanden hat.

6-11 Fit an Telefon (3)

der/die Angestellte 职员 词尾变化按照形容词来变化

anstellen 雇佣 可分v

nun 那么，怎么 用于对话中的承上启下

unverbindlich 不承担义务的，不强制购买的（想了解一下，不一定要买）

vor Ort 现场，当场

einen Termin vereinbaren 约定时间

vorab 事先，提前 adv

eventuell 可能，也许 adv

auftreten 发生，出现 可分v

betreuen 照管，看管，维护，管理

der Notdienst-e 紧急服务

werktags 再工作日 adv

etwas steht jmdm zur Verfügung 某物可供某人使用

besprechen 讨论，商讨，商议

Dialog 2 positiv:

  • klingt freundlich
  • spricht klar und deutlich
  • kleine Hinteregrundgeräusche
  • stellt sich vor und beschreibt die Situation, sagt klar, was sie will
  • ist vorbereitet und hat konkrete Fragen (Stift)
  • hat einen Terminvorschlag und nennt die Adresse
  • versetzt sich in den anderen hinein, fragt nach, bestätigt, ist aufmerksam
  • beachtet Regeln der Höflichkeit: benutzt höfliche Formulierungen und spricht den anderen mit den Name an

Fazit ziehen 得出结论

6-14 Coach Jonas Becktal (3)

nennen etwas/jmdn bei … 用……去称呼某人/某物

den Hörer auflegen 挂电话

verklingen 声音逐渐减弱，逐渐消失

Welche Rahmenbedingungen sollte man bei einem Telefongespräch schaffen?

  • gute Rahmenbedingungen

    • ruhiger Ort, möglichst geringe Hintergrundgeräusche

    • besser für Konzentration

Was kann ich denn noch zur Vorbereitung tun？

  • Vorbereitung
    • die wichtigsten Fragen/Punkte notieren, Stift und Papier bereithalten
    • keine Hektik, nichts vergessen, Gespräch besser lenkbar

Gibt es denn eine besondere Körperhaltung beim Telefonieren, die Sie empfehlen?

  • Verhalten während des Telefongesprächs
    • entspannte, aufrechte Körperhaltung, Hörer nicht zwischen Brust und Kopf klemmen, nur telefonieren und nichts nebenbei machen, lächeln, nicht tippen oder zwischendurch mit anderen sprechen, sondern aufs Telefonat konzentrieren

Muss man denn sonst noch etwas beachten？

  • Missverständnisse vermeiden
    • den Namen langsam und deutlich sprechen, nicht nuscheln, beachten, dass der andere Zeit braucht zum Verstehen, zwischendurch immer mal wieder kurz resümieren, am Ende das Ergebnis kurz zusammenfassen

Und wie beende ich ein Telefongespräch am besten?

  • Ende des Telefongesprächs
    • sich bedanken, Gesprächspartner beim Namen nennen, warten, bis das letzte Wort gesprochen ist

6-21 als, als ob, als wenn 非现实比较从句

“仿佛，好像，表现得像……似的”

动词使用第二虚拟式

als 引导的非现实比较从句，动词第二位

als wenn/als ob 引导的非现实比较从句，动词位于句末构成框架结构

非现实比较从句一般在表示感官感受，感觉，行为举止的动词后面，比如

  • Ich habe das Gefühl, …

  • Ich fühle mich, …

  • Es kommt mir so vor, …

  • Es sieht so aus, …

  • Es hört sich so an, …

  • Er benimmt sich, …

  • Er verhält sich, …

    und so weiter.

Seite 107, 3

  1. Meine Kollegin verhält sich, als ob die Chefin wäre. 我的女同事表现得像她老板似的。
  2. Sie tut immer so, als wüsste sie alles. 她搞得好像什么都知道一样。
  3. Es kommt mir so vor, als ob sie nicht kritikfähig wäre. 我感觉她好像经不起批评。
  4. Sie benimmt sich so, als wäre das Büro ihr Zuhause. 她表现得办公室就是她的家一样。
  5. Es sieht so aus, als wenn auch andere Kollegen Probleme mit ihr hätten. 看起来好像其他同事也不喜欢她。

Seite 107, 4

  • Ich bin im Moment mit meiner Arbeitsstelle sehr zufrieden.
  • Respekt - Respekt steigert die Motivation. Im Berufsleben möchte wohl jeder für seine Arbeit geschätzt und respektiert werden.
  • Offenheit - Ein offener Umgang ist das A und O einer positiven Kommunikationskultur. Nur wenn Kollegen und Vorgesetzte ehrlich miteinander umgehen, lassen sich Konflikte schnell lösen.

6-22 Fit für die Prüfung (1)

Jeder ist ein Genie. Aber wenn Sie einen Fisch nach seiner Fähigkeit beurteilen, auf einen Baum zu klettern, wird er sein ganzes Leben lang in dem Glauben leben, dass er dumm ist. – Albert Einstein

  1. sich auf eine Prüfung vorbereiten 为考试做准备

  2. sich die Zeit einteilen 合理安排时间

  3. sich eine Pause gönnen/einteilen 让自己休息一下/合理安排休息时间

  4. an Prüfungsangst leiden 患有考试恐惧症

  5. den Stoff beherrschen/vorbereiten/einteilen 掌握知识/准备学习材料/合理分配学习材料

  6. sich[Dativ] Informationen einprägen 牢记信息

  7. eine Prüfung bestehen 通过考试

  8. durch eine Prüfung fallen 未通过考试

drankommen 轮到，到来 可分v

6-25 Die richtige Vorbereitung

sich[A] etwas[D] widmen 把时间精力用于…

ablenken 使转移注意力，分散注意力 可分v

stets 总是

bei jemandem mit etwas angeben

Die richtige Vorbereitung

  • genau über Prüfung informieren;

  • Überblick über Stoff verschaffen;

  • Liste mit Themen;

  • Zeitplan (realistisch!);

  • Pausen einplanen;

  • Wiederholungszeit und Puffertage einplanen;

  • am letzten Tag: kein neuer Stoff, Gesamtwiederholung;

  • der Freizeit nachgehen – Ablenkung;

  • Verunsicherungen meiden: Freunde mit Prüfungsangst, Alleskönner;

  • schlimmstmöglichen Fall durchspielen: wegen Durchfallen geht Welt nicht unter

6-26 Am Prüfungstag

der Blutzucker-/ 血糖

der Traubenzucker-/ 葡萄糖

der Blutzuckerspiegel 血糖水平

konstant 不变的，恒定的 adj

bereits = schon 已经

losgehen 动身，出发，开始 可分v

etwas[Dativ] positiv entgegensehen 积极看待某事 可分v

die Gelegenheit-en 时机，机遇

Mühe geben 努力，下功夫

die Formulierung-en 表述，表达，措辞

Am Prüfungstag

  • gut frühstücken;

  • Traubenzucker mitnehmen;

  • rechtzeitiges Losgehen;

  • dem Tag positiv entgegensehen;

  • Aufgaben in Ruhe durchlesen;

  • erst leichte, dann schwere machen;

  • Antworten noch mal durchlesen;

  • Zeit richtig einteilen;

  • ordentlich schreiben;

  • für mündliche Prüfung das Positive bewusst machen: kürzer als schriftliche, Korrektur der Antworten leichter möglich, Nachfragen möglich, Prüfer sind auch Menschen

Denkpause

  • also 用于承上启下：因此，所以；表示结论：那就是说

  • nun 用于承上启下：那么，怎么

  • na ja 表示勉强同意：那好吧，那就这样

  • tja 表示犹豫、思考、窘迫、气馁等：唉，嗯

6-27 Email von Lukas (1)

wahnsinnig 非常，极其

viel um die Ohren haben 焦头烂额

anstehen 有待处理 可分v

die Abschlussprüfung-en 毕业考试，结业考试

kein Land sehen = überlastet sein 超负荷的

der Bammel-/ 害怕，心慌

etwas auf Lager haben 充足地准备好某物，手头备有某物

6-28 Email von Lukas (2)

Lieber Lukas,

herzlichen Dank für deine E-mail.

Ich verstehe deine Situation bzw. deine Prüfungsangst sehr gut, weil ich auch unter die gelitten haben.

Aus meiner persönlichen Erfahrung kann ich nur sagen, dass Prüfungsangst eine deutlich spürbare 明显的，感受得到的 Angst in der Prüfungsvorbereitung, wahrend der Prüfung sogar nach der Prüfung ist. Dagegen ist eine psychologische Beratung hilfreich. Dort habe ich mich schon mehrmals berate lassen.

Ich kann dir das, was ich da kennengelernt habe, einfach weitergeben. Um die Prüfungsangst zu bewältigen 克服 muss man zuerst die verstehen. Bammel 恐惧 und Lampenfieber 怯场 vor Prüfung sind normal. Die meisten von uns sind vor und in Prüfungssituationen aufgeregt, haben feuchte Hände oder gehen ständig auf die Toilette. 手心冒汗或者经常上厕所 Starke Prüfungsangst blockiert uns oder macht uns vielleicht sogar in Form eines Blackout denk- und handlungsunfähig. 严重的考试焦虑会阻碍我们或让大脑短路，甚至可能使我们无法思考或行动。

Zweiten muss man wissen, warum er Prüfungsangst hat. Ich hatte Prüfungsangst, weil ich von meinen Eltern häufig überfordert wurden. Noch ein wichtiger Punkt ist: Immer daran denken, dass es noch etwas Schlimmeres gibt! Sollen du durch die Prüfung fallen, geht davon die Welt auch nicht unter.

Außerdem soll man natürlich rechtzeitig mit der Vorbereitung anfangen. Eine richtige, individuell passende Lernmethode und eine richtige Zeiteinteilung sorgen für eine optimale Vorbereitung.

Dann soll man die Prüfungssituation immer wieder üben. Vergiss bitte nicht, ausreichend zu schlafen!

Ich hoffe, dass meine Tipps dir helfen würden. Ich glaube, dass du deine Abschlussprüfung locker schaffst!

Und natürlich möchte ich mit dir und Isabella zusammen deinen Abschluss feiern. Für dich habe ich immer Zeit. Wenn du mit allen Prüfungen fertig bist, können wir uns dann treffen.

Ich wünsche dir dann viel Erfolg bei den Abschlussprüfungen!

Viele Grüße,

XXX

6-29 Email von Lukas (3)

Pro- und Contra-Argument 赞成和反对的论据、论点

zu einer Entscheidung kommen = eine Entscheidung treffen 做决定

Drei Fotos

Lerngruppe – pro:

in der Gruppe können Fragen geklärt werden;

在小组中可以答疑

wenn einer den anderen etwas erklärt, wird es ihm dadurch klarer;

当一个人向其他人解释知识点时，自己对知识点就会更清晰

mehr Spaß am Lernen, Angst vergeht dadurch;

一起学习更快乐，恐惧随之消失

Foto signalisiert, dass niemand allein ist mit seinem Problem

照片显示，没人是独自面对问题的

Lerngruppe – contra:

in einer großen Gruppe geht der Einzelne unter;

在一个大组中，个体被弱化了

man hat in der Prüfung auch nicht die Unterstützung einer Gruppe;

考试中也得不到学习小组的扶持

hier wird man leicht abgelenkt.

很容易被分散注意力

Entspannungsübung – pro:

Entspannung;

放松

neue Kraft fürs Weiterlernen;

为继续学习获得新力量

sich Pausen zu gönnen ist wichtig;

短暂休息很重要

Foto spricht den Einzelnen direkt an.

照片直接反映出个人

Entspannungsübung – contra:

Thema „Prüfungsprobleme“ nicht zu erkennen;

未显示“考试问题”

nicht jeder kann sich bei Stress entspannen

不是每个人都可以在压力下放松自己的

Lernender Mann – pro:

zeigt, dass man lernen muss;

表明，人们必须学习

wirkt entspannt, bedeutet, dass er eine gute Zeiteinteilung hat;

显得很放松，意味着他的时间分配很合理

Foto spricht den Einzelnen direkt an.

照片直接反映出个人

Lernender Mann – contra:

Foto sendet falsches Signal: Problemen soll man nicht als Einzelkämpfer

entgegentreten;

照片传递出错误的信号：人们不该独自面对困难

Lernen allein hilft nicht gegen Prüfungsangst

独自学习并不能帮助克服考试恐惧

Redemittel

Vorschläge machen und begründen 提出建议并阐述理由

Wie wär’s, wenn …?

Was hältst du von folgendem Vorschlag: …?

Ich hätte da eine Idee: …

Wir könnten doch …

Ich könnte mir vorstellen, dass wir …

Aus diesem Grund würde ich vorschlagen, dass …

widersprechen 反驳

Dazu habe ich eine andere Meinung: …

Ich bin nicht sicher, ob …

Da möchte ich widersprechen, denn …

Ich würde es besser finden, wenn …

Meinst du nicht, wir sollten lieber …?

Ich finde, wir sollten lieber …

Ich hätte einen anderen Vorschlag.

sich einigen 达成一致

Ja, das klingt gut.

Gut, dann machen wir so.

Schön, dann einigen wir uns also auf …

Wir könnten uns vielleicht auf Folgendes einigen: …

Wie wäre es mit einem Kompromiss; …?

Was halten Sie von einem Kompromiss: …?

Wären Sie damit einverstanden, wenn …?

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 3 Boolean Circuits
entry.content:
Non-uniform model of computation: Boolean circuit model.

In contrast to uniform model like Turing machine.

Boolean circuit: Fixed number of inputs. To study computation of arbitrary inputs, we need a family of Boolean circuits.

Some Definitions

📖Definition of Boolean circuit. A Boolean circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs consists of:

  1. A directed acyclic graph D=(V,A)D=(V,A)D=(V,A) where the in-degree of every node is at most 222.
  2. A labeling ℓ\ellℓ of all nodes g∈Vg\in Vg∈V with \ell(g)\in\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n,\overline{x_1},\cdots,\overline{x_n},\and,\or, eg\}.
  3. A choice of mmm output gates o1,⋯ ,om∈Vo_1,\cdots, o_m\in Vo1​,⋯,om​∈V.

The nodes of DDD is the gates of CCC, the arcs of DDD is the wires of CCC.

Nodes with in-degree 000 are input gates.

The size of CCC is the number of gates.

Fanin of a gate is its in-degree, fanout is its out-degree.

Labeling function should satisfy: For all gates ggg:

  1. If the fanin is 000, then \ell(g)\in\{0,1,x_1,\cdots,x_n,\overline{x_1},\cdots,\overline{x_n},\and,\or, eg\}.
  2. If the fanin is 111, then ℓ(g)=¬\ell(g)= egℓ(g)=¬.
  3. If the fanin is 222, then \ell(g)\in\{\and,\or\}.

A Boolean circuit CCC with nnn inputs and mmm outputs computes a Boolean function f:{0,1}n→{0,1}mf:\{0,1\}^n o\{0,1\}^mf:{0,1}n→{0,1}m.

Implicit negation such as xi‾\overline{x_i}xi​​ can be made explicit by introducing a new gate, thereby at most doubling the size of the circuit.

📖Definition of family of Boolean circuits. A family (Cn)n=0∞(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cn​)n=0∞​ of Boolean circuits, where CnC_nCn​ is a circuit with nnn inputs computes the Boolean function f:{0,1}∗→{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^* o\{0,1\}f:{0,1}∗→{0,1} given by f(x)=C∣x∣(x)f(x)=C_{|x|}(x)f(x)=C∣x∣​(x). We say that (Cn)n=0∞(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cn​)n=0∞​ computes the language L⊆{0,1}⋆L\subseteq\{0,1\}^\starL⊆{0,1}⋆ if (Cn)n=0∞(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cn​)n=0∞​ computes the characteristic function χL:{0,1}⋆→{0,1}\chi_L:\{0,1\}^\star o\{0,1\}χL​:{0,1}⋆→{0,1} of LLL given by χL(x)=1\chi_L(x)=1χL​(x)=1 iff x∈Lx\in Lx∈L.

直白一点：我们说一个布尔电路族 (Cn)n=0∞(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cn​)n=0∞​ 计算~~（接受？）~~语言 LLL，当且仅当该布尔电路族的输入 xxx 属于语言 LLL时，输出结果为 111。

If we want to apply non-Boolean alphabet, we just encode these letters into {0,1}k\{0,1\}^k{0,1}k for some fixed kkk.

📖Definition of SIZESIZESIZE. Let S:N→NS:\mathbb N o\mathbb NS:N→N. SIZE(S(n))SIZE(S(n))SIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by family of Boolean circuit of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)),

We interested in class of languages computed by a family of polynomial size.

P/poly=⋃k>0SIZE(nk).P/poly= igcup_{k>0}SIZE(n^k).P/poly=k>0⋃​SIZE(nk).

📖Definition of log-space/polynomial-time uniform. Let (Cn)n=0∞(C_n)_{n=0}^\infty(Cn​)n=0∞​ be a family of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)). We say that the family is log-space uniform if the function 1n↦Cn1^n\mapsto C_n1n↦Cn​ is computable in space O(log⁡S(n))O(\log S(n))O(logS(n)). The family is polynomial-time uniform if the function is computable in time (S(n))O(1)(S(n))^{O(1)}(S(n))O(1).

📖Definition of complexity classes of languages computed by families of Boolean circuits. Let S:N→NS:\mathbb N o\mathbb NS:N→N.

  • UL−SIZE(S(n))U_L-SIZE(S(n))UL​−SIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by log-space uniform families of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)).
  • UP−SIZE(S(n))U_P-SIZE(S(n))UP​−SIZE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by polynomial-time uniform families of Boolean circuits of size O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)).

Boolean Formulas

📖Definition of Boolean formulas. A Boolean formula (aka de Morgan formula) is a Boolean circuit where the underlying directed graph is a tree.

合取范式 conjunctive normal form CNF

析取范式 disjunctive normal form DNF

🎯Theorem 14. Any Boolean function f:{0,1}n→{0,1}f:\{0,1\}^n o\{0,1\}f:{0,1}n→{0,1} is computed by a CNF with sss clauses of length nnn and a DNF with ttt terms of length nnn where

s=∣{x∈{0,1}n∣f(x)=0}∣,t=∣{x∈{0,1}n∣f(x)=1}∣.s=|\{x\in\{0,1\}^n|f(x)=0\}|,\t=|\{x\in\{0,1\}^n|f(x)=1\}|.s=∣{x∈{0,1}n∣f(x)=0}∣,t=∣{x∈{0,1}n∣f(x)=1}∣.

The Shannon Function

The smallest size L(n)L(n)L(n) in which any Boolean function on nnn variables can be computed by a Boolean circuit of size L(n)L(n)L(n).

The function L(n)L(n)L(n) is called the Shannon function.

By DNF/CNF formulas, we have trivial bound L(n)≤n2nL(n)\le n2^nL(n)≤n2n.

Shannon proved that L(n)=Θ(2n/n)L(n)=\Theta(2^n/n)L(n)=Θ(2n/n).

🎯Theorem 15 (Lower Bound on Circuit Size). L(n)>2n4nL(n)> rac{2^n}{4n}L(n)>4n2n​ for n≥9n\ge9n≥9. In fact, the fraction of Boolean functions computed by Boolean circuits of size at most 2n4n rac{2^n}{4n}4n2n​ is at most 2−2n−12^{-2^{n-1}}2−2n−1 for n≥9n\ge9n≥9.

For a given number of inputs n≥1n\ge1n≥1: first give an upper bound on number of Boolean circuits with nnn inputs and 111 output, with at most s≥1s\ge1s≥1 gates. Consider an acyclic ordering of the gates of the circuit and assume the last gate is the output gate.

Different types of gate: input gates have 2n+22n+22n+2 probabilities, negation with one input sss, and/or with two inputs (s2,s2)(s^2,s^2)(s2,s2). Thus we have at most 2n+2+s+s2+s22n+2+s+s^2+s^22n+2+s+s2+s2 options for every gate, meaning that we have at most (2n+2+s+2s2)s(2n+2+s+2s^2)^s(2n+2+s+2s2)s many circuits with at most sss gates.

For s≥n+1s\ge n+1s≥n+1 we have

2n+2+s+2s2≤4s2⇒(2n+2+s+2s2)s≤(2s)2s.2n+2+s+2s^2\le4s^2\\Rarr(2n+2+s+2s^2)^s\le(2s)^{2s}.2n+2+s+2s2≤4s2⇒(2n+2+s+2s2)s≤(2s)2s.

Each of these at most (2s)2s(2s)^{2s}(2s)2s circuits computes precisely one Boolean function. There are exactly 22n2^{2^n}22n different Boolean functions on nnn inputs.

Thus if 22n>(2s)2s2^{2^n}\gt(2s)^{2s}22n>(2s)2s, there must be a Boolean function that is not computed by a Boolean circuit of size sss. (By pigeon hole theorem)

Let n≥9,s=2n4nn\ge9,s= rac{2^n}{4n}n≥9,s=4n2n​, which satisfies s≥n+1s\ge n+1s≥n+1, we have

(2s)2s=22slog⁡2(2s)=22n2n(n−1−log⁡n)<22n−1.(2s)^{2s}=2^{2s\log_2(2s)}=2^{ rac{2^n}{2n}(n-1-\log n)}\lt2^{2^{n-1}}.(2s)2s=22slog2​(2s)=22n2n​(n−1−logn)<22n−1.

It follows that less than 22n−12^{2^{n-1}}22n−1 Boolean functions on nnn inputs are computed by Boolean circuits of size at most 2n4n rac{2^n}{4n}4n2n​.

Turing Machines versus Boolean Circuits

Oblivious Turing machine can efficiently be converted to a family of Boolean circuits.

🤔Proposition 1. Let T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n and suppose LLL is computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded oblivious Turing machine. Then L∈SIZE(T(n))L\in SIZE(T(n))L∈SIZE(T(n)).

Any configuration of oblivious Turing machine on input xxx can be encoded by a binary string of length O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) s.t. every symbol of every work tape corresponds to a fixed number of positions of the encoding.

We can build the Boolean circuit for input length nnn in O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) steps. Proof by induction.

Proposition 1 and Theorem 4 result in some inclusion relation.

🎯Theorem 16. DTIME(T(n))⊆SIZE(T(n)log⁡T(n))DTIME(T(n))\subseteq SIZE(T(n)\log T(n))DTIME(T(n))⊆SIZE(T(n)logT(n)) for T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n.

Turing machine is supplied with an advice string in addition to the input, where the advice string is specific to the input length.

📖Definition of Advice classes. Let C\mathcal CC be a class of languages and f:N→Nf:\mathbb N o\mathbb Nf:N→N a function. Define C/f(n)\mathcal C/f(n)C/f(n) to be the class of languages LLL for which there exist L′∈CL'\in\mathcal CL′∈C satisfying that for all input lengths nnn, there is an advice string yny_nyn​ of length f(n)f(n)f(n) s.t. for all xxx of length nnn, we have x∈Lx\in Lx∈L iff ⟨x,yn⟩∈L′\langle x,y_n angle\in L'⟨x,yn​⟩∈L′. For a family F\mathcal FF of functions F:N→NF:\mathbb N o\mathbb NF:N→N, we let C/F=⋃f∈FC/f(n)\mathcal C/\mathcal F= igcup_{f\in\mathcal F}\mathcal C/f(n)C/F=⋃f∈F​C/f(n).

🎯Theorem 17. Let S(n)≥nS(n)\ge nS(n)≥n. Then SIZE(S(n))⊆DTIME(S(n)2)/O(S(n)log⁡S(n))SIZE(S(n))\subseteq DTIME(S(n)^2)/O(S(n)\log S(n))SIZE(S(n))⊆DTIME(S(n)2)/O(S(n)logS(n)).

The advice string (length nnn) is an encoding of the circuit CnC_nCn​, which is a string of length O(S(n)log⁡S(n))O(S(n)\log S(n))O(S(n)logS(n)).

Assume that the gates of CnC_nCn​ are given in the encoding in acyclic order. On input xxx of length nnn and advice CnC_nCn​, a Turing machine can evaluate CnC_nCn​ on input xxx, evaluating the gates in the given acyclic ordering and storing all intermediate outputs.

To evaluate each gate we need to retrieve the computed value of its inputs, which will take O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) time. Doing this for all O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) gates leads to O(S(n)2)O(S(n)^2)O(S(n)2).

🎯Corollary 1. Let T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n. Then DTIME(T(n)O(1))/T(n)O(1)=SIZE(T(n)O(1))DTIME(T(n)^{O(1)})/T(n)^{O(1)}=SIZE(T(n)^{O(1)})DTIME(T(n)O(1))/T(n)O(1)=SIZE(T(n)O(1))

Proof by Definition of advice class and Theorem 17.

🎯Theorem 18. Let T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n and suppose the function 1n↦T(n)1^n\mapsto T(n)1n↦T(n) is computable in space O(log⁡T(n))O(\log T(n))O(logT(n)). Then DTIME(T(n))⊆UL−SIZE(T(n)log⁡T(n))DTIME(T(n))\subseteq U_L-SIZE(T(n)\log T(n))DTIME(T(n))⊆UL​−SIZE(T(n)logT(n)).

🎯Theorem 19. Let (S(n))≥n(S(n))\ge n(S(n))≥n. Then UL−SIZE(S(n))⊆DTIME(S(n)O(1))U_L-SIZE(S(n))\subseteq DTIME(S(n)^{O(1)})UL​−SIZE(S(n))⊆DTIME(S(n)O(1)).

🎯Corollary 2. Let T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n and suppose that function 1n↦T(n)1^n\mapsto T(n)1n↦T(n) is computable in space O(log⁡T(n))O(\log T(n))O(logT(n)). Then DTIME(T(n)O(1))=UL−SIZE(T(n)O(1))DTIME(T(n)^{O(1)})=U_L-SIZE(T(n)^{O(1)})DTIME(T(n)O(1))=UL​−SIZE(T(n)O(1)).

In particular, we have P=UL−SIZE(nO(1))P=U_L-SIZE(n^{O(1)})P=UL​−SIZE(nO(1)).

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 2 Nondeterminism and Determinism
entry.content:
The sequence of transitions is called computation history.

Non-deterministic Turing machine will crush also when there is no possible next step according to the transition relation.

Non-deterministic Time and Space Complexity

Worst-case definition of time and space to solve a issue by non-deterministic Turing machine.

Let MMM be a non-deterministic Turing machine. For given input x∈Σ∗x\in\Sigma^*x∈Σ∗,

  • timeM(x)time_M(x)timeM​(x) is the maximum number of computation steps that MMM performs on input xxx until halting.
  • spaceM(x)space_M(x)spaceM​(x) is the maximum number of cell on work tapes that are some point scanned by a tape head during computation.

📖Definition of non-deterministic complexity classes:

Let T:N→NT:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NT:N→N and S:N→NS:\mathbb N\rarr NS:N→N be functions with T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n.

NTIME(T(n))NTIME(T(n))NTIME(T(n)) is the class of languages computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine.

NSPACE(T(n))NSPACE(T(n))NSPACE(T(n)) is the class of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine.

Non-deterministic Hierarchy Theorems

🎯Theorem 7 (Non-deterministic Space Hierarchy Theorem). Let S2(n)≥log⁡nS_2(n)\ge\log nS2​(n)≥logn be space constructible. If S1(n)=o(S2(n))S_1(n)=o(S_2(n))S1​(n)=o(S2​(n)), then

NSPACE(S1(n))⊊NSPACE(S2(n)).NSPACE(S_1(n))\subsetneq NSPACE(S_2(n)).NSPACE(S1​(n))⊊NSPACE(S2​(n)).

和 上一课 的定理 3 一样。存储空间越多，“识别的语言”也就越多。

Proof by Immerman–Szelepcsényi theorem.

For non-deterministic time: rely on technique “delayed diagonalization”. 延迟对角化

🎯Theorem 8 (Time-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine). Let T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n and suppose MMM is a T(n)T(n)T(n) time-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine with kkk work tapes. Then there exists a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded non-deterministic Turing machine with 222 work tapes s.t. L(M)=L(M′)L(M)=L(M')L(M)=L(M′).

🎯Theorem 9 (Non-deterministic Time Hierarchy Theorem). Let T2(n)≥nT_2(n)\ge nT2​(n)≥n be time constructible and non-decreasing. If T1(n)T_1(n)T1​(n) satisfies T1(n+1)=o(T2(n))T_1(n+1)=o(T_2(n))T1​(n+1)=o(T2​(n)), then

NTIME(T1(n))⊊NTIME(T2(n))NTIME(T_1(n))\subsetneq NTIME(T_2(n))NTIME(T1​(n))⊊NTIME(T2​(n))

花的时间越长，解决问题就越多。

Proof by constructing MMM s.t. L(M)∉NTIME(T1(n))L(M)\not\in NTIME(T_1(n))L(M)∈NTIME(T1​(n)).

Relating Deterministic and Non-deterministic Computation

🎯Theorem 10. Let T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n. Then NTIME(T(n))⊆DSPACE(T(n))NTIME(T(n))\subseteq DSPACE(T(n))NTIME(T(n))⊆DSPACE(T(n)).

🎯Theorem 11. Let S(n)≥log⁡nS(n)\ge\log nS(n)≥logn. Then NSPACE(S(n))⊆DTIME(2O(S(n)))NSPACE(S(n))\subseteq DTIME(2^{O(S(n))})NSPACE(S(n))⊆DTIME(2O(S(n))).

Savitch’s Theorem

Better than NSPACE(S(n))⊆DSPACE(2O(S(n)))NSPACE(S(n))\subseteq DSPACE(2^{O(S(n))})NSPACE(S(n))⊆DSPACE(2O(S(n))).

🎯Theorem 12 (Savitch’s Theorem). Let S(n)≥log⁡nS(n)\ge\log nS(n)≥logn. Then

NSPACE(S(n))⊆DSPACE(S(n)2).NSPACE(S(n))\subseteq DSPACE(S(n)^2).NSPACE(S(n))⊆DSPACE(S(n)2).

Hard proof

The Immerman–Szelepcsényi Theorem

Non-deterministic space is closed under the operation of taking complements.

coNSPACE(S(n))coNSPACE(S(n))coNSPACE(S(n)): The class of complement languages of languages in NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n))NSPACE(S(n)).

🎯Theorem 13 (Immerman–Szelepcsényi theorem). Let S(n)≥log⁡nS(n)\ge\log nS(n)≥logn. Then

coNSPACE(S(n))=NSPACE(S(n)).coNSPACE(S(n))=NSPACE(S(n)).coNSPACE(S(n))=NSPACE(S(n)).

Non-deterministic Time and Space Complexity Classes

NL=NSPACE(log⁡n)NP=⋃k>0NTIME(nk)NEXP=⋃k>0NTIME(2nk)NL=NSPACE(\log n)\\NP=\bigcup_{k\gt0}NTIME(n^k)\\NEXP=\bigcup_{k\gt0}NTIME(2^{n^k})NL=NSPACE(logn)NP=k>0⋃​NTIME(nk)NEXP=k>0⋃​NTIME(2nk)

Relations:

  • Due to Savitch’s theorem, there is no need for defining NSPACENSPACENSPACE.

  • NL⊆NP⊆PSPACE⊆NEXPNL\subseteq NP\subseteq PSPACE\subseteq NEXPNL⊆NP⊆PSPACE⊆NEXP.

  • By non-deterministic time and space hierarchy theorems: NL⊊PSPACENL\subsetneq PSPACENL⊊PSPACE, NP⊊NEXPNP\subsetneq NEXPNP⊊NEXP.

Thus, L⊆NL⊆P⊆NP⊆PSPACE⊆EXP⊆NEXPL\subseteq NL\subseteq P\subseteq NP\subseteq PSPACE\subseteq EXP\subseteq NEXPL⊆NL⊆P⊆NP⊆PSPACE⊆EXP⊆NEXP.

Summary of Complexity Classes

  1. L (Logarithmic Space)
    • Definition: LLL consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine using O(log⁡n)O(\log n)O(logn) space.
    • Example: Determining if a path exists between two nodes in an undirected graph using depth-first search with a space-efficient representation.
  2. NL (Non-deterministic Logarithmic Space)
    • Definition: NLNLNL consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a non-deterministic Turing machine using O(log⁡n)O(\log n)O(logn) space.
    • Example: Determining if a path exists between two nodes in a directed graph (also known as the reachability problem).
  3. P (Polynomial Time)
    • Definition: PPP consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine in polynomial time, O(nk)O(n^k)O(nk) for some constant kkk.
    • Example: Sorting an array using algorithms like Merge Sort or Quick Sort.
  4. NP (Non-deterministic Polynomial Time)
    • Definition: NPNPNP consists of all decision problems for which a given solution can be verified in polynomial time by a deterministic Turing machine. Equivalently, problems solvable by a non-deterministic Turing machine in polynomial time.
    • Example: The Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT).
  5. PSPACE (Polynomial Space)
    • Definition: PSPACEPSPACEPSPACE consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine using polynomial space.
    • Example: Generalized games like chess, checkers, and go with a polynomial bound on the number of moves.
  6. EXP (Exponential Time)
    • Definition: EXPEXPEXP consists of all decision problems that can be solved by a deterministic Turing machine in exponential time, O(2p(n))O(2^{p(n)})O(2p(n)) for some polynomial p(n)p(n)p(n).
    • Example: Solving the traveling salesman problem using a brute-force search over all possible paths.
  7. NEXP (Non-deterministic Exponential Time)
    • Definition: NEXPNEXPNEXP consists of all decision problems solvable by a non-deterministic Turing machine in exponential time, O(2p(n))O(2^{p(n)})O(2p(n)) for some polynomial p(n)p(n)p(n).
    • Example: Certain advanced combinatorial problems that require guessing an exponentially long solution and verifying it in exponential time.

We don’t know whether these inclusions are strict. But we usually assume that all the inclusions are strict.

P=NPP=NPP=NP implies EXP=NEXPEXP=NEXPEXP=NEXP; EXP≠NEXPEXP\neq NEXPEXP=NEXP implies P≠NPP\neq NPP=NP.
