The sequence of transitions is called computation history.

Non-deterministic Turing machine will crush also when there is

entry.title: 算法和计算复杂度 1 Turing Machines, Time and Space
entry.content:
Theory of Algorithms and Computational Complexity

Lecturer: Kristoffer Arnsfelt Hansen

☠️☠️☠️The most difficult (no “one of”) course in my master’s study.☠️☠️☠️

Brief Intro to TACC

Study of efficient computation

1960s Hartmanis, Stearns - Time Hierarchy Theorem.

Turing machine, register based machine can simulate each other.

Turing Machines

Turing machines - simple, and has some nice properties:

  • Clean definition of complexity (time and space)
  • Straightforward to non-determinism and randomness.

Consider “offline multi-tape sequential Turing machine”

Turing machine is a finite-state machine that can access and modify chars written on “tapes” according to some rules.

Formal Definition

Turing machine MMM with one input tape and kkk work tapes. It includes:

  • Finite set QQQ: set of states

    • Element s∈Qs\in Qs∈Q: start state
    • Element yes∈Qyes\in Qyes∈Q: accept state
    • Element no∈Qno\in Qno∈Q: reject state

  • Finite set Γ\GammaΓ: the tape alphabet

    • non-empty finite set Σ⊆Γ\Sigma\subseteq\GammaΣ⊆Γ: input alphabet

  • Element Δ∈Γ╲Σ\Delta\in\Gamma\diagdown\SigmaΔ∈Γ╲Σ: blank symbol

  • Function

    δ:(Q╲{yes,no})×(Σ∪{Δ})×Γk→Q×(Γ╲{Δ})k×{L,S,R}k+1\delta:(Q\diagdown\{yes,no\})\times(\Sigma\cup\{\Delta\})\times\Gamma^k\rarr Q\times(\Gamma\diagdown\{\Delta\})^k\times\{L,S,R\}^{k+1}δ:(Q╲{yes,no})×(Σ∪{Δ})×Γk→Q×(Γ╲{Δ})k×{L,S,R}k+1

    is the transition function.

状态转移方程的意思：

转移前：(Q╲{yes,no})(Q\diagdown\{yes,no\})(Q╲{yes,no}) 代表转移前状态，不能是接受或拒绝态（因为接受或拒绝就停机了）；(Σ∪{Δ})(\Sigma\cup\{\Delta\})(Σ∪{Δ}) 代表输入字符；Γk\Gamma^kΓk 代表之前当前针头分别指 kkk 个工作纸带对应位置的字符。

转移后：QQQ 代表转移后的状态，可以是接受或拒绝态；(Γ╲{Δ})k(\Gamma\diagdown\{\Delta\})^k(Γ╲{Δ})k 表示针头分别在 kkk 个工作纸带上对应位置写入的字符；{L,S,R}k+1\{L,S,R\}^{k+1}{L,S,R}k+1 表示接下了输入纸带和 kkk 个工作纸带应该左移（LLL）、右移（RRR），还是不动（SSS）。

Transition Function has following properties:

  1. MMM will stop operation when entering yesyesyes or nonono state.
  2. MMM marks all cells visited on its work tapes

The operation of MMM:

  • k+1k+1k+1 two-way infinite tapes. One for input, the rest for work.
  • The cells of each work tape are numbered by the set Z\mathbb ZZ.
  • Input tape on which the cell 1,⋯ ,∣x∣1,\cdots,|x|1,⋯,∣x∣ are filled with char xix_ixi​. The other cells are filled with Δ\DeltaΔ.
  • Each tape has a tape head, which initially stays at position 000.
  • The machine MMM maintain an element of AAA as its internal state.

The computation of MMM:

  • Move the tapes according to transition function
  • If input head is called to “move left” at position 000, or “move right” at position ∣x∣+1|x|+1∣x∣+1, let MMM “crash”. (So there are ∣x∣+2|x|+2∣x∣+2 legal cell for input tape head)
  • When MMM enters yesyesyes or nonono, it stops. We called MMM halts. (M(x)=yesM(x)=yesM(x)=yes or M(x)=noM(x)=noM(x)=no)

Turing machine can be seen as language acceptor useful for decision problems whether the language is formal language, i.e., the language computed by MMM is L(M)={x∈Σ∣M(x)="yes"}L(M)=\{x\in\Sigma|M(x)="yes"\}L(M)={x∈Σ∣M(x)="yes"}.

An Extension on Turing Machine

Add an additional output tape which is write-only.

Λ\LambdaΛ: non-empty finite set, output alphabet. (Usually Λ=Σ\Lambda=\SigmaΛ=Σ)

In each step of computation MMM can choose to write a single symbol to the output tape. Then transition function:

δ:(Q╲{yes,no})×(Σ∪{Δ})×Γk→Q×(Γ╲{Δ})k×(Λ∪{ϵ})×{L,S,R}k+1\delta:(Q\diagdown\{yes,no\})\times(\Sigma\cup\{\Delta\})\times\Gamma^k\\\rarr Q\times(\Gamma\diagdown\{\Delta\})^k\times(\Lambda\cup\{\epsilon\})\times\{L,S,R\}^{k+1}δ:(Q╲{yes,no})×(Σ∪{Δ})×Γk→Q×(Γ╲{Δ})k×(Λ∪{ϵ})×{L,S,R}k+1

ϵ\epsilonϵ here means write nothing.

Such a Turing machine is also called a transducer.

Time and Space Complexity

For a given input x∈Σ∗x\in\Sigma^*x∈Σ∗:

  • timeM(x)time_M(x)timeM​(x) is the number of computational steps that MMM performs on input xxx until halting.
  • spaceM(x)space_M(x)spaceM​(x) is the total number of cells on the work tapes that are at some point scanned by a tape head during computation on input xxx.

Both time and space can be infinite. Space can be infinite when MMM does not halt.

📖Definition of time/space-bounded: let T:N→NT:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NT:N→N and S:N→NS:\mathbb N\rarr\mathbb NS:N→N be functions with T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n. We say MMM is T(n)T(n)T(n) time-bounded, if for every x∈Σ∗x\in\Sigma^*x∈Σ∗ we have timeM(x)≤T(∣x∣)time_M(x)\le T(|x|)timeM​(x)≤T(∣x∣). Similarly, MMM is S(n)S(n)S(n) space-bounded, if for every x∈Σ∗x\in\Sigma^*x∈Σ∗ we have spaceM(x)≤S(∣x∣)space_M(x)\le S(|x|)spaceM​(x)≤S(∣x∣).

Then define the first complexity classes based on time/space bounds.

📖Definition of DTIME,DSPACEDTIME,DSPACEDTIME,DSPACE: DTIME(T(n))DTIME(T(n))DTIME(T(n)) is the class of languages computed by a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded Turing machine and DSPACE(S(n))DSPACE(S(n))DSPACE(S(n)) is the class of languages computed by a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) space Turing machine.

DDD 代表 deterministic （确定）。确定性图灵机每次状态转移只有一种。

NNN 代表 non-deterministic （非确定）。非确定性图灵机每次状态转移可能有多种，机器随机选择其中的一种进行转移。

Why OOO notation here?

  1. Compressing several tapes symbols to one class by an arbitrary linear factor.

  2. WLOG, one work tape can simulate kkk work tapes by special marking char.

    也就是说可以用一个标记字符把一个工作纸带分成 kkk 份。

📖Definition of time/space-constructible: TTT is time-constructible if there is a O(T(n))O(T(n))O(T(n)) time-bounded Turing machine computing the function 1n↦1T(n)1^n\mapsto 1^{T(n)}1n↦1T(n). SSS is space-constructible if there is a O(S(n))O(S(n))O(S(n)) time-bounded Turing machine computing the function 1n↦1S(n)1^n\mapsto 1^{S(n)}1n↦1S(n).

Universal Turing Machines

Universal Turing machine has a fixed amount of work tapes and a fixed tape alphabet.

Set of states QQQ is identified with positive integers from 111 to ∣Q∣|Q|∣Q∣.

Σ\SigmaΣ and Γ\GammaΓ is also identified with positive integers.

δ\deltaδ can be encoded by its function table.

Given: encoding of a Turing machine MMM with kkk work tapes with an encoding of an input xxx to MMM. (encoding of xxx is concatenation of each char in xxx).

🎯Theorem 1. For any k≥1k\ge1k≥1, there exist a Turing machine UkU_kUk​ with k+1k+1k+1 work tapes s.t. when given as input an encoding of a Turing machine MMM with kkk work tapes together with an encoding of an input xxx, simulates the computation of MMM on input xxx using time O(timeM(x))O(time_M(x))O(timeM​(x)) and space O(spaceM(x))O(space_M(x))O(spaceM​(x)).

“Simulates” here means Uk+1U_{k+1}Uk+1​ provides same output, terminal state as MMM.

Sublogarithmic Space

Usually assume that S(n)≥log⁡nS(n)\ge\log nS(n)≥logn.

What if S(n)=o(log⁡n)S(n)=o(\log n)S(n)=o(logn)? In this case Turing machine can’t even be able to describe the position of the input tape head.

O(1)O(1)O(1) space-bounded Turing machine is equivalent to a two-way finite automaton.

To accept non-regular language, the minimal space should be O(log⁡log⁡n)O(\log\log n)O(loglogn).

Storage configuration: a state of MMM, position of tape heads, non-black portions of the work tapes. # storage configuration: at most ∣Q∣sk∣Γ∣s+k−1=2O(s)|Q|s^k|\Gamma|^{s+k-1}=2^{O(s)}∣Q∣sk∣Γ∣s+k−1=2O(s).

🎯Theorem 2. Let MMM be a S(n)S(n)S(n) space-bounded Turing machine for a function S(n)=o(log⁡log⁡n)S(n)=o(\log\log n)S(n)=o(loglogn). Then MMM is in fact O(1)O(1)O(1) space-bounded.

Proof via contradiction.

Storage configuration is periodic.

MMM will produce at most 22O(s)2^{2^{O(s)}}22O(s) crossing sequences.

Turing Machine Configurations

Configuration 被翻译为“格局”……无力吐槽

A configuration of a Turing machine MMM with kkk work tapes:

  1. State of MMM
  2. Positions of k+1k+1k+1 tapes head
  3. Non-blank portions of the work tapes

Observation: If a Turing machine repeats a configuration, it will enter an infinite loop, infinitely repeating the computation taking place between two repeating configurations.

The Space Hierarchy Theorem

Idea: More resources means more can be computed.

🎯Theorem 3: Let S2(n)≥log⁡nS_2(n)\ge\log nS2​(n)≥logn be space constructible. If S1(n)=o(S2(n))S_1(n)=o(S_2(n))S1​(n)=o(S2​(n)), then

DSPACE(S1(n))⊊DSPACE(S2(n)).DSPACE(S_1(n))\subsetneq DSPACE(S_2(n)).DSPACE(S1​(n))⊊DSPACE(S2​(n)).

中文简单解释一下：图灵机的可用渐进存储空间越多，那么解决的问题也就越多。

It suffices to construct a O(S2(n))O(S_2(n))O(S2​(n)) space bounded Turing machine MMM s.t. L(M)∉DSPACE(S1(n))L(M)\not\in DSPACE(S_1(n))L(M)∈DSPACE(S1​(n)).

Input xxx of length n=∣x∣n=|x|n=∣x∣:

  1. Mark S2(n)S_2(n)S2​(n) cells of work tape using the space constructability of S2S_2S2​. During the remaining computation:
    • Ensuring that computation does not use more than S2(n)S_2(n)S2​(n) additional cells of work tape. This is done by immediately halting (reject).
    • Ensuring that computation does not run for more than 22S2(n)2^{2S_2(n)}22S2​(n) steps, by keeping time with a binary counter on 2S2(n)2S_2(n)2S2​(n) bits. (accept)
  2. Check if the input is on the form x=0i1wx=0^i1wx=0i1w, here www is an encoding of a Turing machine with a single work tape. Otherwise halt by rejecting.
  3. Simulate M′M'M′ on input xxx using the universal Turing machine U1U_1U1​. If this causes M′M'M′ to halt, halt and reject if M′M'M′ accepts. Otherwise accept.

Then analysis MMM and M′M'M′…

Tape Reduction and Oblivious Turing Machines

A T(n)T(n)T(n) time-bounded computation of a Turing machine with any number of work tapes can be simulated by a O(T(n)2)O(T(n)^2)O(T(n)2) time-bounded Turing machine with a single work tape. (Simple divide work tape into kkk tracks.)

This is used to prove DTIME(T1(n))⊊DTIME(T2(n))DTIME(T_1(n))\subsetneq DTIME(T_2(n))DTIME(T1​(n))⊊DTIME(T2​(n)) when T2(n)>nT_2(n)>nT2​(n)>n is time-constructible and (T1(n))2=o(T2(n))(T_1(n))^2=o(T_2(n))(T1​(n))2=o(T2​(n)).

📖Definition of oblivious: Let MMM be a Turing Machine. MMM is oblivious if for any n≥1n\ge1n≥1 and any input xxx of length n=∣x∣n=|x|n=∣x∣, during computation with input xxx and until MMM halts, the location of all tape heads of MMM is a function of nnn and the number ttt of steps of the computation so far.

It is easy to modify the O(T(n)2)O(T(n)^2)O(T(n)2) to be oblivious by first copying the input to an additional track, and thereafter keeping the input head stationary.

🎯Theorem 4: Let T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n and suppose MMM is a T(n)T(n)T(n) time-bounded Turing machine with kkk work tapes. Then there exist a O(T(n)log⁡T(n))O(T(n)\log T(n))O(T(n)logT(n)) time-bounded oblivious Turing machine M′M'M′ with 222 work tapes s.t. L(M)=L(M′)L(M)=L(M')L(M)=L(M′).

Hard proof.

The Time Hierarchy Theorem

🎯Theorem 5: Let T2(n)≥nT_2(n)\ge nT2​(n)≥n be time constructible. If T1(n)≥nT_1(n)\ge nT1​(n)≥n satisfies T1(n)log⁡T1(n)=o(T2(n))T_1(n)\log T_1(n)=o(T_2(n))T1​(n)logT1​(n)=o(T2​(n)), then

DTIME(T1(n))⊊DTIME(T2(n)).DTIME(T_1(n))\subsetneq DTIME(T_2(n)).DTIME(T1​(n))⊊DTIME(T2​(n)).

Proof by tape reduction.

Time and Space Complexity Classes

There are some standard complexity classes given by natural classes of time and space bounds.

L=DSPACE(log⁡n)P=⋃k>0DTIME(nk)PSPACE=⋃k>0DSPACE(nk)EXP=⋃k>0DTIME(2nk)L=DSPACE(\log n)\\P=\bigcup_{k>0}DTIME(n^k)\\PSPACE=\bigcup_{k>0}DSPACE(n^k)\\EXP=\bigcup_{k>0}DTIME(2^{n^k})L=DSPACE(logn)P=k>0⋃​DTIME(nk)PSPACE=k>0⋃​DSPACE(nk)EXP=k>0⋃​DTIME(2nk)

Trivially, L⊆P⊆PSPACE⊆EXPL\subseteq P\subseteq PSPACE\subseteq EXPL⊆P⊆PSPACE⊆EXP.

A space bounded Turing machine cannot repeat a configuration without entering an infinite loop, thus DSPACE(S(n))⊆DTIME(2O(S(n)))DSPACE(S(n))\subseteq DTIME(2^{O(S(n))})DSPACE(S(n))⊆DTIME(2O(S(n))) for S(n)>log⁡nS(n)>\log nS(n)>logn.

Unknown: whether any of the inclusions are strict. But time and space hierarchy theorems give that L⊊PSPACEL\subsetneq PSPACEL⊊PSPACE and P⊊EXPP\subsetneq EXPP⊊EXP.

LLL means LOGSPACELOGSPACELOGSPACE, PPP denotes PTIMEPTIMEPTIME, EXPEXPEXP denotes EXPTIMEEXPTIMEEXPTIME.

Obviously(???really???), DTIME(T(n))⊆DSPACE(T(n))DTIME(T(n))\subseteq DSPACE(T(n))DTIME(T(n))⊆DSPACE(T(n)), showing that space is more “valuable than” time. More precisely, DTIME(T(n))⊆DSPACE(T(n)/log⁡T(n))DTIME(T(n))\subseteq DSPACE(T(n)/\log T(n))DTIME(T(n))⊆DSPACE(T(n)/logT(n)) for T(n)≥nT(n)\ge nT(n)≥n.

The Padding Technique

Whether L⊆PL\subseteq PL⊆P and PSPACE⊆EXPPSPACE\subseteq EXPPSPACE⊆EXP are strict is related.

🎯Theorem 6: If L=PL=PL=P, then PSPACE=EXPPSPACE=EXPPSPACE=EXP.

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.2 13-14 Fortæl om ferier og oplevelser
entry.content:
Datid

3 种类型

Gruppe 1：词尾 -ede

Gruppe 2：词尾 -te

Gruppe 3：不规则变化，fx:

  • tager - tog
  • kan - kunne
  • finder - fandt
  • spørger - spurgte
  • sidder - sad
  • nyder - nød
  • drikker - drak

情态动词 modalverber 的过去式

都是不规则变化

kan - kunne

skal - skulle

vil - ville

må - måtte

Esme på kunstmuseum

udstilling -en -er -erne 展览

er spændt på at infinitiv 急切期待做某事

vente -r -de -t 等待

gå -r gik -et 走

gå ind 走进

omvisning -en -er -erne 参观

fortale -r fortalte fortalt 告诉，说出

flot 漂亮的，美好的

Solen skinnede, og himlen var helt blå. 阳光普照，天空很蓝。（有点小学生写作文的感觉）

nød -en 享受

plakat -en -er -erne 海报

Reference til sted: ‘hvor’ og ‘der’

der

对于两个单独句子，第二句中提到的地点如果和第一句中提到的地点相同，则可以使用 der 替代。

Fx.

  • Vi kom til en hyggelig lille by. Vi spiste frokost i byen.
  • Vi kom til en hyggelig lille by. Der spiste vi frokost.

⚠️注意动词第二位原则！

hvor

对于关系从句，从句中提到的地点如果和主句中的相同，则可以用 hvor 替代，并充当关系代词。

Fx.

  • Vi kom til en plads. Der var et stort marked på pladsen.
  • Vi kom til en plads, hvor der var et stort marked.

⚠️注意从句的语序是 hvor + 主语 + 谓语！

Tidsledsætninger med ‘da’

关系从句中，关系代词 da 指代过去的时间。

Fx.

  • Hendes veninde står og venter. Hun kommer til museet.
  • Hendes veninde stod og ventede, da hun kom til museet.

区分：

  • 在一周内 om en uge
  • 一周的时长 i en uge

i sommerhalvåret 在夏季学期

i vinterhalvåret 在冬季学期

deltage -r deltog -t 参与，参加

grundlovsdag 宪法日

grundlov -en -e -ene 宪法，基本法

udflugt -en -er -erne 游览，观光

ørken -en -er -erne 沙漠

klatre -r -de -t 爬

entry.title: 随机算法 14 Markov Chains and Random Walks
entry.content:
Lecture notes by Elias Koutsoupias from Oxford

Markov Chains

Definitions

A discrete-time finite Markov chain is a sequence of random variables X=X0,X1,X2,⋯X=X_0,X_1,X_2,\cdotsX=X0​,X1​,X2​,⋯ taking values in a finite set of states {1,2,⋯ ,n}\{1,2,\cdots,n\}{1,2,⋯,n} s.t. ∀t∈N:\forall t\in\mathbb N:∀t∈N:

Pr⁡(Xt+1=j∣Xt=i)=Qi,j,\Pr(X_{t+1}=j|X_t=i)=Q_{i,j},Pr(Xt+1​=j∣Xt​=i)=Qi,j​,

where Q=(Qi,j)Q=(Q_{i,j})Q=(Qi,j​) is an n×nn\times nn×n stochastic transition matrix.

XtX_tXt​ represents the state of the Markov chain at time ttt and the matrix QQQ encodes the state-to-state transition probabilities. The characteristic property of a Markov chain is that the distribution of XtX_tXt​ depends only on Xt−1X_{t-1}Xt−1​. The conditional probability above is independent of the time ttt.

The ttt-step transition probabilities are given by the power matrix QtQ^tQt, i.e.,

Pr⁡(Xs+t=j∣Xs=i)=Qi,jt,\Pr(X_{s+t}=j|X_s=i)=Q_{i,j}^t,Pr(Xs+t​=j∣Xs​=i)=Qi,jt​,

∀s,t∈N\forall s,t\in\mathbb N∀s,t∈N. Thus,

Pr⁡(Xt=j)=∑i=1nQi,jt⋅Pr⁡(X0=i).\Pr(X_t=j)=\sum_{i=1}^nQ_{i,j}^t\cdot\Pr(X_0=i).Pr(Xt​=j)=i=1∑n​Qi,jt​⋅Pr(X0​=i).

A Markov chain is completely determined by the distribution of X0X_0X0​ and the transition matrix QQQ.

A Markov chain can be represented as a weighted directed graph whose vertices are the states of the chain and in which there is an edge (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) of weight Qi,jQ_{i,j}Qi,j​ whenever Qi,j>0Q_{i,j}\gt0Qi,j​>0. We define the weight of a path to the product of the weights of the edges along the path, i.e. the probability to take the path. Then the sum of the weights of all length-kkk paths iii to jjj is Qi,jkQ_{i,j}^kQi,jk​.

The term random walk usually refers to the random process in which a particle moves on a graph, selecting the next node uniformly at random from the adjacent nodes. It is the special case of a Markov chain when for every state iii all probabilities Qi,jQ_{i,j}Qi,j​ for j≠ij\neq ij=i are equal and Qi,i=0Q_{i,i}=0Qi,i​=0.

A lazy random walk is similar but Qi,i=1/2Q_{i,i}=1/2Qi,i​=1/2.

Randomized 2-SAT

Given a 2-CNF formula, either find a satisfying assignment or determine that no such assignment exists.

CNF aka conjunctive normal form，合取范式，形如 ()\and()\and()

2-CNF 就是 ()\and()\and()\cdots\and()，括号内里面是两个布尔变量的析取。

DNF aka disjunctive normal form，析取范式，形如 ()\or()\or()

2-SAT is solvable in polynomial time (in fact linear time).

There is a polynomial time randomized algorithm for 2-CNF formulas whose analysis is based on a random walk.

Pseudo-code

Randomized 2-SAT(φ)(\varphi)(φ)

  • Pick a random assignment
  • Repeat 2n22n^22n2 times or until a satisfying assignment is found
    • Pick an unsatisfied clause CCC
    • Pick a literal in CCC uniformly at random, and flip its value
  • Return current assignment if satisfying, else return unsatisfiable

Analysis

If the φ\varphiφ is not satisfiable then the algorithm returns unsatisfiable. However, if φ\varphiφ is satisfiable then the algorithm might not find a satisfying assignment. We analyze the probability that the algorithm gives correct answer.

Consider φ\varphiφ is satisfiable. Let SSS be a particular assignment that satisfies φ\varphiφ.

Then we bound the probability that algorithm finds SSS. If φ\varphiφ is not satisfied by an assignment AAA there must be an unsatisfied clause CCC. Observe that one or both literals of CCC must have different truth values under AAA and SSS. Thus if we flip a random literal in CCC then the probability that we increase the agreement between AAA and SSS is either 1/21/21/2 or 111.

Writing AtA_tAt​ for the assignment after ttt iterations of the main loop and XtX_tXt​ for the number of variables in which AtA_tAt​ agrees with SSS, we have

Pr⁡(Xt+1=1∣Xt=0)=1Pr⁡(Xt+1=i+1∣Xt=i)≥1/2,i∈{1,⋯ ,n−1}Pr⁡(Xt+1=i−1∣Xt=i)≤1/2,i∈{1,⋯ ,n−1}Pr⁡(Xt+1=n∣Xt=n)=1\Pr(X_{t+1}=1|X_t=0)=1\\\Pr(X_{t+1}=i+1|X_t=i)\ge1/2,i\in\{1,\cdots,n-1\}\\\Pr(X_{t+1}=i-1|X_t=i)\le1/2,i\in\{1,\cdots,n-1\}\\\Pr(X_{t+1}=n|X_t=n)=1Pr(Xt+1​=1∣Xt​=0)=1Pr(Xt+1​=i+1∣Xt​=i)≥1/2,i∈{1,⋯,n−1}Pr(Xt+1​=i−1∣Xt​=i)≤1/2,i∈{1,⋯,n−1}Pr(Xt+1​=n∣Xt​=n)=1

If we replace inequalities with equations, then XXX becomes a Markov chain on the state space [n][n][n]. The Markov chain of this process is:

  flowchart LR0((0))1((1))2((2))3((...))4((n))0-->|1|11-->|1/2|01-->|1/2|22-->|1/2|12-->|1/2|33-->|1/2|23-->|1/2|44-->|1|4

The chain describes the movement of a particle on a line: it is an example of a one-dimensional random walk with one reflecting and one absorbing barrier.

The expected time until Xt=nX_t=nXt​=n is an upper bound on the expected number of steps for the 2-SAT algorithm to find SSS.

Let hjh_jhj​ be the expected time for XXX to first reach nnn starting at jjj. Then we have

hn=0h0=1+h1hj=1+hj−12+hj+12,j∈{1,⋯ ,n−1}h_n=0\\h_0=1+h_1\\h_j=1+\frac{h_{j-1}}{2}+\frac{h_{j+1}}{2},j\in\{1,\cdots,n-1\}hn​=0h0​=1+h1​hj​=1+2hj−1​​+2hj+1​​,j∈{1,⋯,n−1}

This is a linear system of equations in n+1n+1n+1 unknowns.

By some deduction, we have hj=hj+1+2j+1h_j=h_{j+1}+2j+1hj​=hj+1​+2j+1. Combining with hn=0h_n=0hn​=0, we get that hj=n2−j2h_j=n^2-j^2hj​=n2−j2. Thus hj≤n2∀jh_j\le n^2\forall jhj​≤n2∀j.

Let TTT denote the number of steps for the 2-SAT algorithm to find assignment SSS starting from some arbitrary assignment. By Markov’s inequality, we have

Pr⁡(T≥2n2)≤E[T]2n2≤n22n2=12\Pr(T\ge2n^2)\le\frac{\mathbb E[T]}{2n^2}\le \frac{n^2}{2n^2}=\frac{1}{2}Pr(T≥2n2)≤2n2E[T]​≤2n2n2​=21​

Theorem: If φ\varphiφ is satisfiable then the 2-SAT algorithm returns a satisfying assignment with probability at least 1/21/21/2. If φ\varphiφ is unsatisfiable then the 2-SAT algorithm is always correct.

The failure probability can be decreased to 2−N2^{-N}2−N by repeating the loop 2Nn22Nn^22Nn2 instead of 2n22n^22n2 times.

Randomized 3-SAT

Extending the randomized algorithm for 2-SAT to 3-SAT.

3-SAT is NP-complete. We can use O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n) exhaustive search to solve it.

Suppose a given 3-CNF formula φ\varphiφ has a satisfying assignment SSS. Let AtA_tAt​ be the assignment after ttt steps and let XtX_tXt​ denote the number of propositional variables in which AtA_tAt​ agrees with SSS. Similarly,

Pr⁡(Xt+1=j+1∣Xt=j)≥1/3Pr⁡(Xt+1=j−1∣Xt=j)≤2/3\Pr(X_{t+1}=j+1|X_t=j)\ge1/3\\\Pr(X_{t+1}=j-1|X_t=j)\le2/3Pr(Xt+1​=j+1∣Xt​=j)≥1/3Pr(Xt+1​=j−1∣Xt​=j)≤2/3

Then by replacing ≤≥\le\ge≤≥ into ===, we turn the process XXX into Markov chain:

  flowchart LR0((0))1((1))2((2))3((...))4((n))0-->|1|11-->|2/3|01-->|1/3|22-->|2/3|12-->|1/3|33-->|2/3|23-->|1/3|44-->|1|4

The expected time for the resulting chain to reach state nnn is an upper bound for the expected time of the algorithm to find a satisfying valuation.

In this case, there is twice likelihood to move away from nnn as to move towards nnn.

Let hjh_jhj​ denote expected number of steps to reach nnn when starting from state jjj. Then we have the following system of equations

hn=0hj=2hj−13+hj+13+1h0=h1+1h_n=0\\h_j=\frac{2h_{j-1}}{3}+\frac{h_{j+1}}{3}+1\\h_0=h_1+1hn​=0hj​=32hj−1​​+3hj+1​​+1h0​=h1​+1

By solving this linear system, we get hj=hj+1+2j+2−3h_j=h_{j+1}+2^{j+2}-3hj​=hj+1​+2j+2−3 for all jjj.

With hn=0h_n=0hn​=0 this leads to hj=2n+2−2j+2−3(n−j)h_j=2^{n+2}-2^{j+2}-3(n-j)hj​=2n+2−2j+2−3(n−j).

The above bound shows that the expected number of flips to find SSS is at most O(2n)O(2^n)O(2n). This bound is useless. However, we can improve the performance of this procedure by adapting random restarts into search. A random truth assignment leads to a binomial distribution over the states of the Markov chain XXX centered around the state n/2n/2n/2.

Since Markov chain has a tendency to move towards state 000, after running it for a little while we are better off restarting with a random distribution than continuing to flip literals.

After random restart, by Chernoff bounds, the current assignment differs from SSS is approximately n/2n/2n/2 positions with high probability.

There is an algorithm trying to find a satisfying assignment in N=O((4/3)nn)N=O((4/3)^n\sqrt n)N=O((4/3)nn​) phases. where each phase starts with a random restart and consists of 3n3n3n literal flips.

Pseudo-code

Randomized 3-SAT(φ)(\varphi)(φ)

  • Repeat NNN times or until a satisfying assignment is found
    • Pick a random assignment
    • Repeat 3n3n3n times or until a satisfying assignment is found
      • Pick an unsatisfied clause CCC
      • Pick a literal in CCC uniformly at random, and flip its value
  • Return current assignment if satisfying, else return unsatisfiable

Theorem: If φ\varphiφ is satisfiable then the 3-SAT algorithm returns a satisfying assignment with probability at least 1/21/21/2. If φ\varphiφ is unsatisfiable then the 2-SAT algorithm is always correct.

Let qjq_jqj​ be the probability to reach position nnn with 3n3n3n steps starting from position n−jn-jn−j. We have

qj≥C3jj(2/3)j(1/3)2j,q_j\ge C_{3j}^j(2/3)^j(1/3)^{2j},qj​≥C3jj​(2/3)j(1/3)2j,

since this is the probability to make exactly 2j2j2j right moves and jjj left moves in the first 3j≤3n3j\le3n3j≤3n steps.

By Stirling’s formula:

2πm(me)m≤m!≤22πm(me)m,\sqrt{2\pi m}(\frac{m}{e})^m\le m!\le2\sqrt{2\pi m}(\frac{m}{e})^m,2πm​(em​)m≤m!≤22πm​(em​)m,

we have

C3jj=(3j)!j!(2j)!≥cj(27/4)j(c=38π).C_{3j}^j=\frac{(3j)!}{j!(2j)!}\\\ge\frac{c}{\sqrt j}(27/4)^j\\(c=\frac{\sqrt3}{8\sqrt\pi}).C3jj​=j!(2j)!(3j)!​≥j​c​(27/4)j(c=8π​3​​).

Thus when j>0j\gt0j>0,

qj≥C3jj(2/3)j(1/3)2j≥cj(27/4)j(2/3)j(1/3)2j≥cj12j.q_j\ge C_{3j}^j(2/3)^j(1/3)^{2j}\\\ge \frac{c}{\sqrt j}(27/4)^j(2/3)^j(1/3)^{2j}\\\ge\frac{c}{\sqrt j}\frac{1}{2^j}.qj​≥C3jj​(2/3)j(1/3)2j≥j​c​(27/4)j(2/3)j(1/3)2j≥j​c​2j1​.

The probability of success drops exponentially with the distance jjj between the initial random assignment of the phase and the satisfying truth assignment. But by Chernoff bounds, the probability that this distance is away from n/2n/2n/2 also drops exponentially.

Having established a lower bound for qjq_jqj​ we now obtain a lower bound for qqq, the probability to reach state nnn with 3n3n3n steps in case the initial state of the random walk is determined by a random assignment. We have

q≥∑j=0nPr⁡(walk starts at n−j)⋅qj≥12n+∑j=1nCnj(1/2)ncj12j≥cn(1/2)n∑j=0nCnj(1/2)j=cn(3/4)n.q\ge\sum_{j=0}^n\Pr(\text{walk starts at }n-j)\cdot q_j\\\ge\frac{1}{2^n}+\sum_{j=1}^nC_n^j(1/2)^n\frac{c}{\sqrt j}\frac{1}{2^j}\\\ge\frac{c}{\sqrt n}(1/2)^n\sum_{j=0}^nC_n^j(1/2)^j\\=\frac{c}{n}(3/4)^n.q≥j=0∑n​Pr(walk starts at n−j)⋅qj​≥2n1​+j=1∑n​Cnj​(1/2)nj​c​2j1​≥n​c​(1/2)nj=0∑n​Cnj​(1/2)j=nc​(3/4)n.

The number of phases to find a satisfying assignment is a geometric random variable with parameter qqq, so the expected number of phases to find a satisfying assignment is 1/q1/q1/q. Thus the algorithm finds a satisfying assignment with probability at least 1/21/21/2 after N=2/qN=2/qN=2/q phases.

Stationary Distributions

Definition

Let XXX be a Markov chain with transition matrix QQQ. A probability distribution π\piπ on the set of states is called stationary distribution of XXX if

π=πQ.\pi=\pi Q.π=πQ.

Given states i,ji,ji,j of a Markov chain, the hitting time Hi,jH_{i,j}Hi,j​ is a random variable giving the number of steps to visit state jjj starting from state iii. Formally we have

Hi,j=min⁡{t>0:Xt=j∣X0=i}.H_{i,j}=\min\{t\gt0:X_t=j|X_0=i\}.Hi,j​=min{t>0:Xt​=j∣X0​=i}.

We define hi,j=E[Hi,j]h_{i,j}=\mathbb E[H_{i,j}]hi,j​=E[Hi,j​] to be the mean hitting time.

In general hi,jh_{i,j}hi,j​ may be infinite. Certainly hi,j=∞h_{i,j}=\inftyhi,j​=∞ if jjj is not reachable from iii in the underlying graph, or, if iii can reach a state kkk from which jjj is no longer reachable. We therefore restrict attention to Markov chains whose underlying graph consists of a single strongly connected component. We call such chains irreducible.

We can still have hi,j=∞h_{i,j}=\inftyhi,j​=∞ in an irreducible chain.

Consider Markov chain XXX with set of states {1,2,3,⋯ }\{1,2,3,\cdots\}{1,2,3,⋯} and transition matrix QQQ, where Qi,i+1=i/(i+1)Q_{i,i+1}=i/(i+1)Qi,i+1​=i/(i+1) and Qi,1=1/(i+1)Q_{i,1}=1/(i+1)Qi,1​=1/(i+1). Starting at state 111, the probability not to have returned to state 111 with ttt steps is

∏j=1tjj+1=1t+1.\prod_{j=1}^t\frac{j}{j+1}=\frac{1}{t+1}.j=1∏t​j+1j​=t+11​.

Thus we return to state 111 almost surely, but the expected return time is

h1,1=[H1,1]=∑j=1∞Pr⁡(H1,1≥j)=∑j=1∞1j+1=∞h_{1,1}=\mathbb[H_{1,1}]=\sum_{j=1}^\infty\Pr(H_{1,1}\ge j)\\=\sum_{j=1}^\infty\frac{1}{j+1}=\inftyh1,1​=[H1,1​]=j=1∑∞​Pr(H1,1​≥j)=j=1∑∞​j+11​=∞

In finite irreducible Markov chain, the mean hitting time between any pair of states is always finite.

Theorem: For any pair of states i,ji,ji,j in a finite irreducible Markov chain, hi,j<∞h_{i,j}\lt\inftyhi,j​<∞.

Let ddd be the diameter of the underlying graph, let ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0 be the smallest positive entry of the transition matrix QQQ. Then for any pair of states i,ji,ji,j, if the chain is started in iii then it visits jjj within ddd steps with probability at least ϵd\epsilon^dϵd.

hi,j=E[Hi,j]=∑t=1∞Pr⁡(Hi,j≥t)≤∑t=1∞(1−ϵd)⌊t/d⌋<∞.h_{i,j}=\mathbb E[H_{i,j}]\\=\sum_{t=1}^\infty\Pr(H_{i,j}\ge t)\le\sum_{t=1}^\infty(1-\epsilon^d)^{\lfloor t/d\rfloor}\lt\infty.hi,j​=E[Hi,j​]=t=1∑∞​Pr(Hi,j​≥t)≤t=1∑∞​(1−ϵd)⌊t/d⌋<∞.

A finite irreducible Markov chain has a unique stationary distribution.

Theorem: A finite irreducible Markov chain has a unique stationary distribution π\piπ where πj=1/hj,j\pi_j=1/h_{j,j}πj​=1/hj,j​ for each state jjj.

Stationary distribution represents a time average. On average the chain visits state jjj every hj,jh_{j,j}hj,j​ steps, and thus spends proportion of time πj=1/hj,j\pi_j=1/h_{j,j}πj​=1/hj,j​ in state jjj. We expect that the stationary distribution is also a space average, i.e., the distribution of XtX_tXt​ converges to π\piπ as ttt tends to infinity. However, in general this need not be true.

Definition of period: The period of a state iii in a Markov chain is defined to be gcd⁡{m>0:Qi,im>0}\gcd\{m\gt0:Q_{i,i}^m\gt0\}gcd{m>0:Qi,im​>0}. A state is aperiodic if it has period 111. A Markov chain is aperiodic if all states are aperiodic.

A Markov chain is irreducible and aperiodic iff there exists some power of the transition matrix PPP with all entries strictly positive.

Theorem: Consider a finite, irreducible, aperiodic Markov chain with stationary distribution π\piπ. Then lim⁡n→∞Qn\lim_{n\rarr\infty}Q^nlimn→∞​Qn is the matrix

Q∞=[π1π2⋯πnπ1π2⋯πn⋯⋯⋯⋯π1π2⋯πn]Q^\infty=\left[\begin{array}{cc}\pi_1&\pi_2&\cdots&\pi_n\\\pi_1&\pi_2&\cdots&\pi_n\\\cdots&\cdots&\cdots&\cdots\\\pi_1&\pi_2&\cdots&\pi_n\\\end{array}\right]Q∞=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎡​π1​π1​⋯π1​​π2​π2​⋯π2​​⋯⋯⋯⋯​πn​πn​⋯πn​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎤​

If follows that for any initial distribution xxx we have xQb→xQ∞=πxQ^b\rarr xQ^\infty=\pixQb→xQ∞=π as n→∞n\rarr\inftyn→∞, i.e., the chain converges to the stationary distribution from any starting point.

Random walks on undirected graphs

Let G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) be a finite, undirected and connected graph. The degree of a vertex v∈Vv\in Vv∈V is the number d(v)d(v)d(v) of edges incident to vvv. A random walk on GGG is a Markov chain modeling a particle that moves along the edges of GGG and which is equally likely to take any outgoing edge at a given vertex/

Formally a random walk on GGG has set of states is VVV and for each edge {u,v}∈E\{u,v\}\in E{u,v}∈E the probability to transition from uuu to vvv is 1/d(u)1/d(u)1/d(u).

Claim: A random walk on GGG is aperiodic iff GGG is not bipartite.

Theorem: A random walk on a connected graph GGG has a unique stationary distribution π\piπ, where

πv=d(v)2E.\pi_v=\frac{d(v)}{2E}.πv​=2Ed(v)​.

所有点的度数之和等于 2∣E∣2|E|2∣E∣.

(πP))u=∑v∈N(u)d(v)2∣E∣1d(v)=d(u)2∣E∣=πu∀u∈V(\pi P))_u=\sum_{v\in N(u)}\frac{d(v)}{2|E|}\frac{1}{d(v)}=\frac{d(u)}{2|E|}=\pi_u\forall u\in V(πP))u​=v∈N(u)∑​2∣E∣d(v)​d(v)1​=2∣E∣d(u)​=πu​∀u∈V

Corollary: Let hu,vh_{u,v}hu,v​ denote the expected number of steps to go from vertex uuu to vertex vvv. Then for any vertex uuu we have

hu,u=2∣E∣d(u)h_{u,u}=\frac{2|E|}{d(u)}hu,u​=d(u)2∣E∣​

Theorem: If u,vu,vu,v are adjacent then hv,u<2∣E∣h_{v,u}\lt 2|E|hv,u​<2∣E∣.

omitted.

Theorem: The cover time of a connected graph GGG with nnn nodes and mmm edges is at most 4nm4nm4nm.

omitted

s-t connectivity

We bound on the cover time of random walks to design an impressively simple space efficient algorithm for the fundamental problem of s-t connectivity. In this problem we are given an undirected graph with nnn nodes, not necessarily connected. We are also given two nodes s,ts,ts,t and we want to find out whether s,ts,ts,t are connected.

Pseudo-code

s-t connectivity(G,s,t)(G,s,t)(G,s,t)

  • start a random walk from sss
  • If ttt is reached in 4n34n^34n3 steps then return reachable else return unreachable

No false positives in the algorithm.

By Markov’s inequality, the algorithm outputs a path from sss to ttt with probability 1/21/21/2.

The algorithm only needs to store a constant number of vertex-addresses at any one time.

If follows that we can decide reach-ability in undirected graph in O(log⁡n)O(\log n)O(logn) space using randomization.

Lecture notes by Elias Koutsoupias from Oxford

entry.title: 随机算法 13 Nearest Neighbor Search with Different Distance Metrics
entry.content:
Recall

Recall the problem of nearest neighbor search: Randomized ccc-approximate RRR-near neighbor search. Recall that given a set PPP of nnn points in Rd\mathbb R^dRd and parameters R>0,δ>0R\gt0,\delta\gt0R>0,δ>0. Also given a distance function dist:Rd×Rd→Rdist:\mathbb R^d\times\mathbb R^d\rarr\mathbb Rdist:Rd×Rd→R. For a query point qqq, if there is an RRR-near neighbor ppp of qqq (dist(p,q)≤Rdist(p,q)\le Rdist(p,q)≤R), we must report some point p′p'p′ that is a cRcRcR-near neighbor of qqq (dist(p′,q)≤cRdist(p',q)\le cRdist(p′,q)≤cR) with probability 1−δ1-\delta1−δ.

Sensitive Hash Functions. Family of hash functions H\mathcal HH to be (R,cR,P1,P2)(R,cR,P_1,P_2)(R,cR,P1​,P2​)-sensitive for distdistdist if

  1. for all p,q∈Rdp,q\in\mathbb R^dp,q∈Rd with dist(p,q)≤R:Pr⁡h∼H[h(p)=h(q)]≥P1dist(p,q)\le R:\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]\ge P_1dist(p,q)≤R:Prh∼H​[h(p)=h(q)]≥P1​.
  2. for all p,q∈Rdp,q\in\mathbb R^dp,q∈Rd with dist(p,q)≥cR:Pr⁡h∼H[h(p)=h(q)]≤P2dist(p,q)\ge cR:\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]\le P_2dist(p,q)≥cR:Prh∼H​[h(p)=h(q)]≤P2​.

Solutions. With query time O(L(d+tk))O(L(d+tk))O(L(d+tk)) and space O(nd+Ln)O(nd+Ln)O(nd+Ln), where L=O(nln⁡P1/ln⁡P2)L=O(n^{\ln P_1/\ln P_2})L=O(nlnP1​/lnP2​), ttt is the time to evaluate a hash function from HHH and k=log⁡P2(1/n)k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)k=logP2​​(1/n).

Hamming Distance. Hash functions for Hamming distance: a uniform hash function hhh in H\mathcal HH chooses a uniform random bit position and returns the corresponding bit as the hash value. H\mathcal HH was (R,cR,1−R/d,1−cR/d)(R,cR,1-R/d,1-cR/d)(R,cR,1−R/d,1−cR/d)-sensitive and we proved that exponent ρ=ln⁡P1/ln⁡P2\rho=\ln P_1/\ln P_2ρ=lnP1​/lnP2​ satisfies ρ≤1/c\rho\le 1/cρ≤1/c.

Other Distance Measures

l1-distance

For 2 points p,q∈Rdp,q\in\mathbb R^dp,q∈Rd, we have ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​-distance ∑i=1d∣pi−qi∣\sum_{i=1}^d|p_i-q_i|∑i=1d​∣pi​−qi​∣. Given the radius RRR and approximation factor ccc, we can design a sensitive family of hash functions as follows: For a radius www to be determined, consider the family:

H={hi,o(x)=⌊xi−ow⌋∣i∈{1,⋯ ,d},o∈[0,w)}\mathcal H=\left\{h_{i,o}(x)=\left\lfloor\frac{x_i-o}{w}\right\rfloor| i\in\{1,\cdots,d\},o\in[0,w)\right\}H={hi,o​(x)=⌊wxi​−o​⌋∣i∈{1,⋯,d},o∈[0,w)}

To get a hash function from H\mathcal HH, a coordinate iii and offset ooo are drawn uniformly and independently.

The hash value of the point xxx is ⌊(xi−o)/w⌋\lfloor(x_i-o)/w\rfloor⌊(xi​−o)/w⌋.

Consider iii and hi,oh_{i,o}hi,o​ has been chosen, but ooo is still uniform random in [0,w)[0,w)[0,w). For points p,qp,qp,q, hi,o(p)h_{i,o}(p)hi,o​(p) and hi,o(q)h_{i,o}(q)hi,o​(q) equal precisely when ⌊(pi−o)/w⌋=⌊(qi−o)/w⌋\lfloor(p_i-o)/w\rfloor=\lfloor(q_i-o)/w\rfloor⌊(pi​−o)/w⌋=⌊(qi​−o)/w⌋. The expression ⌊(x−oi)/w⌋\lfloor(x-o_i)/w\rfloor⌊(x−oi​)/w⌋ changes value precisely at points x=oi+jwx=o_i+jwx=oi​+jw for j∈Zj\in\mathbb Zj∈Z.

What’s the probability that a point of the form oi+jwo_i+jwoi​+jw lies between pip_ipi​ and qiq_iqi​?

  • If ∣pi−qi∣≥w|p_i-q_i|\ge w∣pi​−qi​∣≥w, then this happens with probability 111.
  • Otherwise, the probability is ∣pi−qi∣/w|p_i-q_i|/w∣pi​−qi​∣/w.

Thus we have Pr⁡[⌊(pi−oi)/w⌋=⌊(qi−oi)/w⌋]=max⁡{0,1−∣pi−qi∣/w}\Pr[\lfloor(p_i-o_i)/w\rfloor=\lfloor(q_i-o_i)/w\rfloor]=\max\{0,1-|p_i-q_i|/w\}Pr[⌊(pi​−oi​)/w⌋=⌊(qi​−oi​)/w⌋]=max{0,1−∣pi​−qi​∣/w}.

Since iii is chosen uniformly, we get

Pr⁡h∼H[h(p)=h(q)]=∑i=1d1dmax⁡{0,1−∣pi−qi∣/w}.\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]=\sum_{i=1}^d\frac{1}{d}\max\{0,1-|p_i-q_i|/w\}.h∼HPr​[h(p)=h(q)]=i=1∑d​d1​max{0,1−∣pi​−qi​∣/w}.

Let us first assume dist(p,q)≤Rdist(p,q)\le Rdist(p,q)≤R. If we choose w≥Rw\ge Rw≥R, then the above simplifies to

Pr⁡h∼H[h(p)=h(q)]=∑i=1d1d⋅(1−∣pi−qi∣/w)=1−∑i=1d∣pi−qi∣dw=1−dist(p,q)dw≥1−Rdw\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]=\sum_{i=1}^d\frac1d\cdot(1-|p_i-q_i|/w)\\=1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^d|p_i-q_i|}{dw}=1-\frac{dist(p,q)}{dw}\ge1-\frac{R}{dw}h∼HPr​[h(p)=h(q)]=i=1∑d​d1​⋅(1−∣pi​−qi​∣/w)=1−dw∑i=1d​∣pi​−qi​∣​=1−dwdist(p,q)​≥1−dwR​

On the other hand, assume dist(p,q)>cRdist(p,q)\gt cRdist(p,q)>cR and assume we choose w≥cRw\ge cRw≥cR. Then we get:

Pr⁡h∼H[h(p)=h(q)]=∑i=1d1dmax⁡{0,1−∣pi−qi∣/w}=∑i=1d1d⋅(1−min⁡{w,∣pi−qi∣}w)=1−∑i=1dmin⁡{w,∣pi−qi∣}dw.\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]=\sum_{i=1}^d\frac{1}{d}\max\{0,1-|p_i-q_i|/w\}\\=\sum_{i=1}^d\frac{1}{d}\cdot(1-\frac{\min\{w,|p_i-q_i|\}}{w})\\=1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^d\min\{w,|p_i-q_i|\}}{dw}.h∼HPr​[h(p)=h(q)]=i=1∑d​d1​max{0,1−∣pi​−qi​∣/w}=i=1∑d​d1​⋅(1−wmin{w,∣pi​−qi​∣}​)=1−dw∑i=1d​min{w,∣pi​−qi​∣}​.

Assume first that ∀i:∣pi−qi∣≤w\forall i:|p_i-q_i|\le w∀i:∣pi​−qi​∣≤w. Then the above equals

1−∑i=1d∣pi−qi∣dw=1−dist(p,q)dw≤1−cRdw1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^d|p_i-q_i|}{dw}=1-\frac{dist(p,q)}{dw}\le1-\frac{cR}{dw}1−dw∑i=1d​∣pi​−qi​∣​=1−dwdist(p,q)​≤1−dwcR​

On the other hand, assume ∃i:∣pi−qi∣>w\exist i:|p_i-q_i|\gt w∃i:∣pi​−qi​∣>w, then the above has upper bound:

Pr⁡h∼H[h(p)=h(q)]=1−∑i=1dmin⁡{w,∣pi−qi∣}dw≤1−wdw≤1−cRdw\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(p)=h(q)]=1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^d\min\{w,|p_i-q_i|\}}{dw}\\\le 1-\frac{w}{dw}\le1-\frac{cR}{dw}h∼HPr​[h(p)=h(q)]=1−dw∑i=1d​min{w,∣pi​−qi​∣}​≤1−dww​≤1−dwcR​

Thus H\mathcal HH is (R,cR.1−R/(dw),1−cR/(dw))(R,cR.1-R/(dw),1-cR/(dw))(R,cR.1−R/(dw),1−cR/(dw))-sensitive if we choose w≥cRw\ge cRw≥cR. This results in L=O(nρ)L=O(n^\rho)L=O(nρ) for

ρ=ln⁡P1ln⁡P2=ln⁡(1−R/(dw))ln⁡(1−cR/(dw))≤ln⁡(1−R/(dw))ln⁡(1−R/(dw))c=1c\rho=\frac{\ln P_1}{\ln P_2}=\frac{\ln(1-R/(dw))}{\ln(1-cR/(dw))}\le\frac{\ln(1-R/(dw))}{\ln(1-R/(dw))^c}=\frac{1}{c}ρ=lnP2​lnP1​​=ln(1−cR/(dw))ln(1−R/(dw))​≤ln(1−R/(dw))cln(1−R/(dw))​=c1​

We also have k=log⁡P2(1/n)=ln⁡(1/n)ln⁡(1−cR/(dw))k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)=\frac{\ln(1/n)}{\ln(1-cR/(dw))}k=logP2​​(1/n)=ln(1−cR/(dw))ln(1/n)​. By 1−x≤exp⁡(−x)1-x\le\exp(-x)1−x≤exp(−x), we have

k=log⁡P2(1/n)=ln⁡(1/n)ln⁡(1−cR/(dw))≤ln⁡(1/n)−cR/(dw)=dwln⁡n/(cR).k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)=\frac{\ln(1/n)}{\ln(1-cR/(dw))}\le\frac{\ln(1/n)}{-cR/(dw)}=dw\ln n/(cR).k=logP2​​(1/n)=ln(1−cR/(dw))ln(1/n)​≤−cR/(dw)ln(1/n)​=dwlnn/(cR).

Set Similarity Search

Consider the data consists of sets rather than points.

Input consist of nnn sets S1,⋯ ,SnS_1,\cdots,S_nS1​,⋯,Sn​, all subsets of a universe UUU.

Measure for set similarity: Jaccard coefficient

J(A,B)=∣A∩B∣∣A∪B∣J(A,B)=\frac{|A\cap B|}{|A\cup B|}J(A,B)=∣A∪B∣∣A∩B∣​

The coefficient lies between 000 and 111 with J(A,B)=1J(A,B)=1J(A,B)=1 when AAA and BBB are identical and J(A,B)=0J(A,B)=0J(A,B)=0 when AAA and BBB are disjoint.

The Nearest Neighbor Queries on sets: Given a set CCC, find the set SiS_iSi​ in the data that is most similar to CCC.

Goal: Use the LSH. For LSH we need to distance metric. Which is the opposite of Jaccard coefficient.

distJ(A,B)=1−J(A,B)dist_J(A,B)=1-J(A,B)distJ​(A,B)=1−J(A,B)

How to define LSH function for this distance metric? Use min-wise independent families of hash function. A family of hash functions H:U→R\mathcal H:U\rarr\mathbb RH:U→R is min-wise independent if ∀x∈U,S⊂U\forall x\in U,S\subset U∀x∈U,S⊂U with x∉Sx\notin Sx∈/S, it holds that

Pr⁡h∼H[h(x)<min⁡y∈Sh(y)]=1∣S∣+1.\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(x)\lt\min_{y\in S}h(y)]=\frac{1}{|S|+1}.h∼HPr​[h(x)<y∈Smin​h(y)]=∣S∣+11​.

The above definition means that in any set, each element has exactly the same probability of receiving the smallest hash value. We assume that any h∈Hh\in\mathcal Hh∈H returns distinct values for all x∈Ux\in Ux∈U i.e. h(x)≠h(y)h(x)\neq h(y)h(x)=h(y) for any x≠yx\neq yx=y and any h∈Hh\in\mathcal Hh∈H.

Assume that we have a min-wise independent family of hash functions H\mathcal HH and define from it a new family of hash function GH⊂2U→U:\mathcal G_\mathcal H\subset 2^U\rarr U:GH​⊂2U→U:

GH={gh(A)=arg⁡min⁡x∈Ah(x)∣h∈H}.\mathcal G_\mathcal H=\{g_h(A)=\arg\min_{x\in A}h(x)|h\in\mathcal H\}.GH​={gh​(A)=argx∈Amin​h(x)∣h∈H}.

This definition needs a bit of explanation. The notation 2U2^U2U refers to all subsets of the universe UUU. So GH\mathcal G_\mathcal HGH​ consists of functions that map sets A⊆UA\subseteq UA⊆U to hash values in UUU.

The family GH\mathcal G_\mathcal HGH​ has one function ghg_hgh​ for each function h∈Hh\in\mathcal Hh∈H. To evaluate gh(A)g_h(A)gh​(A), we compute the element x∈Ax\in Ax∈A receiving the smallest hash value when using hhh, and we return that element xxx as the hash value of AAA. Simply speaking, gh(A)g_h(A)gh​(A) returns the element in AAA with smallest hash value according to hhh,

Is GH\mathcal G_\mathcal HGH​ sensitive w.r.t. distJdist_JdistJ​? Consider 2 sets A,BA,BA,B and let x∗=arg⁡min⁡x∈A∪Bh(x)x^*=\arg\min_{x\in A\cup B}h(x)x∗=argminx∈A∪B​h(x) be the element with smallest hash value in the union A∪BA\cup BA∪B. Observe that gh(A)=gh(B)g_h(A)=g_h(B)gh​(A)=gh​(B) iff x∗∈A∩Bx^*\in A\cap Bx∗∈A∩B. Now define for every x∈A∩Bx\in A\cap Bx∈A∩B the event ExE_xEx​ s.t. h(x)<min⁡g∈(A∪B)╲{x}h(y)h(x)\lt\min_{g\in(A\cup B)\diagdown\{x\}}h(y)h(x)<ming∈(A∪B)╲{x}​h(y), i.e., ExE_xEx​ is the event that xxx has the smallest hash value among all elements in A∪BA\cup BA∪B, we have

Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]=Pr⁡h∼H[arg⁡min⁡x∈A∪Bh(x)∈A∩B]=Pr⁡h∼H[⋃x∈A∩BEx]\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]=\Pr_{h\sim H}[\arg\min_{x\in A\cup B}h(x)\in A\cap B]\\=\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[\bigcup_{x\in A\cap B}E_x]gh​∼GH​Pr​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)]=h∼HPr​[argx∈A∪Bmin​h(x)∈A∩B]=h∼HPr​[x∈A∩B⋃​Ex​]

The events ExE_xEx​ are disjoint. Therefore

Pr⁡h∼H[⋃x∈A∩BEx]=∑x∈A∩BPr⁡h∼H[Ex]=∑x∈A∩B1∣(A∪B)╲{x}∣+1=∣A∩B∣∣A∪B∣=J(A,B)\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[\bigcup_{x\in A\cap B}E_x]=\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[E_x]\\=\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\frac{1}{|(A\cup B)\diagdown\{x\}|+1}\\=\frac{|A\cap B|}{|A\cup B|}=J(A,B)h∼HPr​[x∈A∩B⋃​Ex​]=x∈A∩B∑​h∼HPr​[Ex​]=x∈A∩B∑​∣(A∪B)╲{x}∣+11​=∣A∪B∣∣A∩B∣​=J(A,B)

Now we bound P1,P2P_1,P_2P1​,P2​.

  • For P1P_1P1​. Let A,BA,BA,B have distJ(A,B)≤Rdist_J(A,B)\le RdistJ​(A,B)≤R. We see that R≥distJ(A,B)=1−J(A,B)=1−Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]R\ge dist_J(A,B)=1-J(A,B)=1-\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]R≥distJ​(A,B)=1−J(A,B)=1−Prgh​∼GH​​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)], implying Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]≥1−R\Pr_{g_h\sim \mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]\ge1-RPrgh​∼GH​​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)]≥1−R.

  • For P2P_2P2​. Next let A,BA,BA,B have distJ(A,B)>cRdist_J(A,B)\gt cRdistJ​(A,B)>cR. Then we have cR<distJ(A,B)=1−J(A,B)=1−Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]cR\lt dist_J(A,B)=1-J(A,B)=1-\Pr_{g_h\sim \mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]cR<distJ​(A,B)=1−J(A,B)=1−Prgh​∼GH​​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)] implying Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]<1−cR\Pr_{g_h\sim \mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]\lt 1-cRPrgh​∼GH​​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)]<1−cR.

Thus the family GH\mathcal G_\mathcal HGH​ is thus (R,cR,1−R,1−cR)(R,cR,1-R,1-cR)(R,cR,1−R,1−cR)-sensitive.

Then we bound ρ\rhoρ in L=O(nρ)L=O(n^\rho)L=O(nρ):

ρ=ln⁡P1/ln⁡P2=ln⁡(1−R)/ln⁡(1−cR)≤ln⁡(1−R)/ln⁡(1−R)c=1/c.\rho=\ln P_1/\ln P_2=\ln(1-R)/\ln(1-cR)\le\ln(1-R)/\ln(1-R)^c=1/c.ρ=lnP1​/lnP2​=ln(1−R)/ln(1−cR)≤ln(1−R)/ln(1−R)c=1/c.

Then we bound kkk as k=ln⁡P2(1/n)=ln⁡(1/n)/ln⁡(1−cR)k=\ln_{P_2}(1/n)=\ln(1/n)/\ln(1-cR)k=lnP2​​(1/n)=ln(1/n)/ln(1−cR). Analogously,

k≤ln⁡(1/n)/ln⁡(exp⁡(−cR))=ln⁡n/(cR).k\le\ln(1/n)/\ln(\exp(-cR))=\ln n/(cR).k≤ln(1/n)/ln(exp(−cR))=lnn/(cR).

Constructing Min-Wise Independent Families

All of above assumed that we had a min-wise independent family of hash functions H\mathcal HH. Unfortunately it can be proved that such families of hash functions are impossible to construct using a small random seed. However, we can still find efficient families that are only approximately min-wise independent.

It suffices to get reasonable nearest neighbor search structures.

We say that a family of hash function H\mathcal HH is ϵ\epsilonϵ-approximate min-wise independent, if for any x∈Ux\in Ux∈U and any S⊂US\subset US⊂U with x∉Sx\notin Sx∈/S, we have

Pr⁡h∼H[h(x)<min⁡y∈Sh(y)]∈1±ϵ∣S∣+1\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[h(x)\lt\min_{y\in S}h(y)]\in\frac{1\pm\epsilon}{|S|+1}h∼HPr​[h(x)<y∈Smin​h(y)]∈∣S∣+11±ϵ​

Indyk showed that any O(ln⁡(1/ϵ))O(\ln(1/\epsilon))O(ln(1/ϵ))-wise independent family of hash functions is also ϵ\epsilonϵ-approximate min-wise independent. A classic example of kkk-wise independent family of hash function is the following for any prime p>Up\gt Up>U:

H={hak−1,⋯ ,a0(x)=∑i=1k−1aixi mod p∣a0,⋯ ,ak−1∈[p]}.\mathcal H=\left\{ h_{a_{k-1},\cdots,a_0}(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}a_ix^i\text{ mod }p|a_0,\cdots,a_{k-1}\in[p] \right\}.H={hak−1​,⋯,a0​​(x)=i=1∑k−1​ai​xi mod p∣a0​,⋯,ak−1​∈[p]}.

Someone proved that the simple tabulation hash function is ϵ\epsilonϵ-approximate min-wise independent with ϵ=O(lg⁡2n/n1/c)\epsilon=O(\lg^2n/n^{1/c})ϵ=O(lg2n/n1/c) where ccc is number of tables used for the hash function and nnn is the cardinality of the set SSS. So the quality depends on the set cardinalities and therefore simple tabulation hashing works best for rather large sets.

How the approximation affects the sensitivity of the hash function:

Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]=∑x∈A∩BPr⁡h∼H[Ex]≤∑x∈A∩B1+ϵ∣(A∪B)╲{x}∣+1=(1+ϵ)⋅∣A∩B∣∣A∪B∣=(1+ϵ)⋅J(A,B).\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]=\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[E_x]\\\le\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\frac{1+\epsilon}{|(A\cup B)\diagdown\{x\}|+1}\\=(1+\epsilon)\cdot\frac{|A\cap B|}{|A\cup B|}\\=(1+\epsilon)\cdot J(A,B).gh​∼GH​Pr​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)]=x∈A∩B∑​h∼HPr​[Ex​]≤x∈A∩B∑​∣(A∪B)╲{x}∣+11+ϵ​=(1+ϵ)⋅∣A∪B∣∣A∩B∣​=(1+ϵ)⋅J(A,B).

Therefore, for distJ(A,B)>cRdist_J(A,B)\gt cRdistJ​(A,B)>cR, we have

Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]≤(1+ϵ)J(A,B)≤(1+ϵ)(1−distJ(A,B))≤(1+ϵ)(1−cR).\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]\\\le(1+\epsilon)J(A,B)\\\le(1+\epsilon)(1-dist_J(A,B))\\\le(1+\epsilon)(1-cR).gh​∼GH​Pr​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)]≤(1+ϵ)J(A,B)≤(1+ϵ)(1−distJ​(A,B))≤(1+ϵ)(1−cR).

Analogously, we also have

Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]=∑x∈A∩BPr⁡h∼H[Ex]≥∑x∈A∩B1−ϵ∣(A∪B)╲{x}∣+1=(1−ϵ)⋅∣A∩B∣∣A∪B∣=(1−ϵ)⋅J(A,B).\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]=\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\Pr_{h\sim\mathcal H}[E_x]\\\ge\sum_{x\in A\cap B}\frac{1-\epsilon}{|(A\cup B)\diagdown\{x\}|+1}\\=(1-\epsilon)\cdot\frac{|A\cap B|}{|A\cup B|}\\=(1-\epsilon)\cdot J(A,B).gh​∼GH​Pr​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)]=x∈A∩B∑​h∼HPr​[Ex​]≥x∈A∩B∑​∣(A∪B)╲{x}∣+11−ϵ​=(1−ϵ)⋅∣A∪B∣∣A∩B∣​=(1−ϵ)⋅J(A,B).

This implies that for distJ(A,B)≤Rdist_J(A,B)\le RdistJ​(A,B)≤R, we have

Pr⁡gh∼GH[gh(A)=gh(B)]≥(1−ϵ)J(A,B)=(1−ϵ)(1−distJ(A,B))≥(1−ϵ)(1−R).\Pr_{g_h\sim\mathcal G_\mathcal H}[g_h(A)=g_h(B)]\\\ge(1-\epsilon)J(A,B)\\=(1-\epsilon)(1-dist_J(A,B))\\\ge(1-\epsilon)(1-R).gh​∼GH​Pr​[gh​(A)=gh​(B)]≥(1−ϵ)J(A,B)=(1−ϵ)(1−distJ​(A,B))≥(1−ϵ)(1−R).

Thus GH\mathcal G_\mathcal HGH​ is (R,cR,(1−R)(1−ϵ),(1−cR)(1+ϵ))(R,cR,(1-R)(1-\epsilon),(1-cR)(1+\epsilon))(R,cR,(1−R)(1−ϵ),(1−cR)(1+ϵ))-sensitive.

l2-distance

dist(p,q)=∑i=1d(pi−qi)2dist(p,q)=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^d(p_i-q_i)^2}dist(p,q)=i=1∑d​(pi​−qi​)2​

Math Math Math!🤯

Let www be a parameter to be fixed and consider the following family of hash functions

H={ho,u(x)=⌊⟨x,u⟩−ow⌋∣o∈[0,w),u∈Rd}.\mathcal H=\left\{h_{o,u}(x)=\lfloor\frac{\langle x,u\rangle-o}{w}\rfloor|o\in[0,w),u\in\mathbb R^d\right\}.H={ho,u​(x)=⌊w⟨x,u⟩−o​⌋∣o∈[0,w),u∈Rd}.

We simply pick ooo uniformly in [0,w)[0,w)[0,w) and pick vector uuu s.t. each coordinate is independently N(0,1)\mathcal N(0,1)N(0,1) distributed.

Consider two points p,qp,qp,q and two fixed values of ⟨p,u⟩\langle p,u\rangle⟨p,u⟩ and ⟨q,u⟩\langle q,u\rangle⟨q,u⟩ (Once uuu is chosen but ooo is still uniform random). Similar to ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​-distance, we get

⌊⟨p,u⟩−ow⌋=⌊⟨q,u⟩−ow⌋\lfloor\frac{\langle p,u\rangle-o}{w}\rfloor=\lfloor\frac{\langle q,u\rangle-o}{w}\rfloor⌊w⟨p,u⟩−o​⌋=⌊w⟨q,u⟩−o​⌋

with probability max⁡{0,1−∣⟨p−q,u⟩∣/w}\max\{0,1-|\langle p-q,u\rangle|/w\}max{0,1−∣⟨p−q,u⟩∣/w}.

Then consider the distribution of ⟨p−q,u⟩\langle p-q,u\rangle⟨p−q,u⟩:

⟨p−q,u⟩=∑i=1d(pi−qi)ui∼N(0,∑i(pi−qi)2)∼N(0,dist(p,q)2)∼dist(p,q)⋅N(0,1)⇒⟨p−q,u⟩/w∼(dist(p,q)/w)⋅N(0,1)\langle p-q,u\rangle=\sum_{i=1}^d(p_i-q_i)u_i\sim\mathcal N(0,\sum_i(p_i-q_i)^2)\\\sim\mathcal N(0,dist(p,q)^2)\sim dist(p,q)\cdot\mathcal N(0,1)\\\Rarr \langle p-q,u\rangle/w\sim (dist(p,q)/w)\cdot\mathcal N(0,1)\\⟨p−q,u⟩=i=1∑d​(pi​−qi​)ui​∼N(0,i∑​(pi​−qi​)2)∼N(0,dist(p,q)2)∼dist(p,q)⋅N(0,1)⇒⟨p−q,u⟩/w∼(dist(p,q)/w)⋅N(0,1)

By probability density function fff or N(0,1)\mathcal N(0,1)N(0,1):

Pr⁡[h(p)=h(q)]=∫−∞∞12πexp⁡(−x2/2)⋅max⁡{0,1−(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣}dx≥Pr⁡[h(p)=h(q)]=∫−∞∞12πexp⁡(−x2/2)⋅(1−(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣)dx=∫−∞∞12πexp⁡(−x2/2)dx−∫−∞∞12πexp⁡(−x2/2)(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣dx.\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)\cdot\max\{0,1-(dist(p,q)/w)|x|\}dx\\\ge\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)\cdot(1-(dist(p,q)/w)|x|)dx\\=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)dx-\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)(dist(p,q)/w)|x|dx.Pr[h(p)=h(q)]=∫−∞∞​2π​1​exp(−x2/2)⋅max{0,1−(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣}dx≥Pr[h(p)=h(q)]=∫−∞∞​2π​1​exp(−x2/2)⋅(1−(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣)dx=∫−∞∞​2π​1​exp(−x2/2)dx−∫−∞∞​2π​1​exp(−x2/2)(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣dx.

By symmetry and integral of fff is 111, the upper quantity

≥1−2⋅(dist(p,q)/w)⋅12π⋅∫0∞exp⁡(−x2/2)xdx≥1−2⋅(dist(p,q)/w)⋅12π\ge1-2\cdot(dist(p,q)/w)\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\cdot\int_0^\infty\exp(-x^2/2)xdx\\\ge1-2\cdot(dist(p,q)/w)\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}≥1−2⋅(dist(p,q)/w)⋅2π​1​⋅∫0∞​exp(−x2/2)xdx≥1−2⋅(dist(p,q)/w)⋅2π​1​

For p,qp,qp,q with dist less than RRR, this is at least 1−2/π(R/w)1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(R/w)1−2/π​(R/w).

For upper bound on Pr⁡[h(p)=h(q)]\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]Pr[h(p)=h(q)]:

Pr⁡[h(p)=h(q)]=∫−∞∞12πexp⁡(−x2/2)⋅max⁡{0,1−(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣}dx≤∫−∞∞12πexp⁡(−x2/2)⋅(1−(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣)dx+2⋅∫w/dist(p,q)∞12πexp⁡(−x2/2)⋅(dist(p,q)/w)xdx=⋯⋯=1−2/π(dist(p,q)/w)(1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2).\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]=\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)\cdot\max\{0,1-(dist(p,q)/w)|x|\}dx\\\le\int_{-\infty}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)\cdot(1-(dist(p,q)/w)|x|)dx\\+2\cdot\int_{w/dist(p,q)}^\infty\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-x^2/2)\cdot(dist(p,q)/w)xdx\\=\cdots\cdots\\=1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(dist(p,q)/w)(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2}).Pr[h(p)=h(q)]=∫−∞∞​2π​1​exp(−x2/2)⋅max{0,1−(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣}dx≤∫−∞∞​2π​1​exp(−x2/2)⋅(1−(dist(p,q)/w)∣x∣)dx+2⋅∫w/dist(p,q)∞​2π​1​exp(−x2/2)⋅(dist(p,q)/w)xdx=⋯⋯=1−2/π​(dist(p,q)/w)(1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2).

Assume w≫dist(p,q)w\gg dist(p,q)w≫dist(p,q) and ignore (1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2)(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})(1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2). Under this simplification, we get for p,qp,qp,q with dist(p,q)>cRdist(p,q)\gt cRdist(p,q)>cR that Pr⁡[h(p)=h(q)]≤1−2/π(cR/w)\Pr[h(p)=h(q)]\le1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(cR/w)Pr[h(p)=h(q)]≤1−2/π​(cR/w).

The we bound ρ\rhoρ in L=O(nρ)L=O(n^\rho)L=O(nρ):

ρ=ln⁡P1/ln⁡P2=ln⁡(1−2/π(R/w))/ln⁡(1−2/π(cR/w))≤ln⁡(1−2/π(R/w))/ln⁡(1−2/π(R/w))c=1/c\rho=\ln P_1/\ln P_2=\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(R/w))/\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(cR/w))\\\le\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(R/w))/\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(R/w))^c=1/cρ=lnP1​/lnP2​=ln(1−2/π​(R/w))/ln(1−2/π​(cR/w))≤ln(1−2/π​(R/w))/ln(1−2/π​(R/w))c=1/c

If we don’t ignore (1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2)(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})(1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2), then

ρ≤1c(1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2)\rho\le\frac{1}{c(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})}ρ≤c(1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2)1​

By choosing www, we need to estimate on the largest value of dist(p,q)dist(p,q)dist(p,q).

Then we bound kkk.

P2=1−2/π(cR/w)P_2=1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(cR/w)P2​=1−2/π​(cR/w), ignoring (1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2)(1-e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})(1−e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2).

Be have k=log⁡P2(1/n)=ln⁡(1/n)/ln⁡P2=ln⁡(1/n)/ln⁡(1−2/π(cR/w))k=\log_{P_2}(1/n)=\ln(1/n)/\ln P_2=\ln(1/n)/\ln(1-\sqrt{2/\pi}(cR/w))k=logP2​​(1/n)=ln(1/n)/lnP2​=ln(1/n)/ln(1−2/π​(cR/w)).

k≤ln⁡(1/n)/ln⁡(e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2)=ln⁡n/(2/πcR/w)=O(wln⁡n/(cR))k\le\ln(1/n)/\ln(e^{-(w/dist(p,q))^2/2})=\ln n/(\sqrt{2/\pi}cR/w)=O(w\ln n/(cR))k≤ln(1/n)/ln(e−(w/dist(p,q))2/2)=lnn/(2/π​cR/w)=O(wlnn/(cR))

This means we should be careful not to choose www too large.

Recall

Recall the problem of nearest neighbor search

entry.title: Fair Division 8 Strategic Aspects of Fair Divison
entry.content:
Objective: Investigate strategic aspects of fair division, considering Pure Nash equilibria and fairness.

Activities: Review the paper Allocating Indivisible Goods to Strategic Agents: Pure Nash Equilibria and Fairness.

Abstract

What if the agents are strategic?

Goal: whether there exist mechanisms that have pure Nash Equilibria. If so, what is the fairness guarantee for these equilibria?

Focus on EF1, EFX. The answer is positive.

2 algorithms:

  • round-robin (computing EF1 allocation). Its pure Nash equilibria are EF1 w.r.t. true values.
  • cut and choose algorithm (computing EFX allocation for 2 agents). The corresponding allocations not only are EFX, but also satisfy MMS. A weaker result holds for any mechanism for two agents that always has pure Nash equilibria, which all induce EFX allocations.

Introduction

This paper is interested in exploring the problem from a game-theoretic perspective.

Assume that the agents are strategic, i.e., agent may misreport its true valuation for the goods to end up with a bundle of higher total value.

The algorithm takes the input values (which are probably misreported) the agents declare.

The existence of truthful mechanisms. Even for 2 agents, truthfulness and fairness are incompatible by providing impossibility results for every non-trivial fairness notion. So next natural question: Is it possible to have non-truthful mechanisms that are guaranteed to have equilibria with these equilibria always inducing fair allocations?

Contributions

The class of mechanisms that are implementable in polynomial time have pure Nash equilibria for every instance and provide some fairness guarantee as the allocations they produce in their equilibria is non-empty.

  • Round-robin has pure Nash equilibria for every instance, and these equilibria induce allocations that are known properties of round-robin with a novel recursive construction of “nicely structured” bid profiles.
  • Mod-Cut&Choose has pure Nash equilibria for every instance with 2 agents, and these equilibria induce allocations that are always EFX and MMS w.r.t. the underlying true values. For the case of 2 agents, MMS allocations are always EFX allocations; i.e., MMS fairness is stronger. In non-strategic setting, for any ϵ>0\epsilon\gt 0ϵ>0, there are instances in which the output of Mod-Cut&Choose is not (5/6+ϵ)(5/6+\epsilon)(5/6+ϵ)-MMS allocation.
  • A weaker result. All mechanisms that have pure Nash equilibria for every instance with 2 agents and these equilibria induce allocations that are always EFX provide stronger MMS guarantees in these allocations than generic EFX allocations do.

🎯🤔Theorem 1. For n=2n=2n=2, any MMS allocation is also an EFX allocation.

For n=2n=2n=2, MMS allocation is indeed PMMS allocation. Any PMMS allocation is EFX allocation.

🎯🤔Theorem 2. For n=2n=2n=2, any EFX is also 2/32/32/3-MMS allocation. The bound is tight for any m≥4m\ge4m≥4.

Mechanisms and Equilibria

An allocation mechanism M\mathcal MM is an algorithm that takes its input from the agents and allocates all the goods to them.

Assume each agent iii reports a bid vector bib_ibi​, where bij≥0b_{ij}\ge0bij​≥0 is the value agent iii claims to have for good gjg_jgj​. M\mathcal MM takes bid profile b\mathbf bb of bid vectors and outputs an allocation M(b)\mathcal M(\mathbf b)M(b).

Assume that the agents are strategic (They may misreport their true values in order to get a bundle with higher value).

Hence, in general, bi≠(vi(g1),⋯ ,vi(gm))\mathbf b_i\neq(v_i(g_1),\cdots,v_i(g_m))bi​=(vi​(g1​),⋯,vi​(gm​)).

Focus: Fairness guarantees of the pure Nash equilibria of the mechanisms.

Best response.

The profile b\mathbf bb is pure Nash equilibria (PNE) if for each i∈Ni\in Ni∈N, bi\mathbf b_ibi​ is a best response to b−i\mathbf b_{-i}b−i​.

When b\mathbf bb is a PNE and the allocation M(b)\mathcal M(\mathbf b)M(b) has a fairness guarantee, we say that b\mathbf bb is EF1.

Some remarks:

  1. Here we don’t consider too much about the complexity of mechanism.
  2. Any PNE of any α\alphaα-approximation mechanism for computing MMS allocation is an α\alphaα-MMS allocation. This is also true for PROP.

Fairness of Nash Equilibria of Round-Robin

Round-Robin Mechanism takes a bid profile as input. Then RR should also take a permutation NNN as an input to determine the priority of the agents.

WLOG, let the permutation be 1,2,⋯ ,n1,2,\cdots,n1,2,⋯,n.

It’s known that RR outputs EF1 allocation when all agents have additive valuation functions.

Pseudo-code: Omitted, can refer to here.

🤔Lemma 1. If bi\mathbf b_ibi​ is the truthful bid of agent iii, then the allocation A\mathcal AA returned by Round-Robin is EF1 from iii’s perspective. Moreover, if i=1i=1i=1, then A\mathcal AA is EF from agent 111’s perspective, i.e., ∀j∈N,v1(A1)≥v1(Aj)\forall j\in N,v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(A_j)∀j∈N,v1​(A1​)≥v1​(Aj​).

Truth-telling is not a Pure Nash equilibria. Example omitted.

RR is known to have PNE for any instance in which no agent values two goods exactly the same and at least some such equilibria are easy to compute. Strict preference ranking is convenient as it reduces the number of corner case with which one has to deal. This results can be extended to general additive valuation functions.

For only 2 agents, all PNE of round-robin are EF1 w.r.t. the real valuation functions. Complex even for n=3n=3n=3.

Nash Equilibria of Round-Robin for Any Number of Agents

Agent 1 have no envy toward any other bundle whenever agent 1 bids truthfully. Agent 1 is EF-satisfied.

No matter what agent 1 bids, it is possible to “replace” the agent with an imaginary version of agent, who

  1. does not affect the allocation
  2. bids truthfully
  3. considers the bundles of the allocation to be as valuable as the original agent 1 though they were

🎯🤔Theorem 4. For any fair division instance I\mathcal II, every PNE of round-robin is EF1 w.r.t. v\mathbf vv.

Proving it reduces to showing that the agent who picks first in the round-robin is EF-satisfied as long as the agent bids a best response to other agent’ bids.

Definition of partial slide: Let {q1,q2,⋯ ,qm}\{q_1,q_2,\cdots,q_m\}{q1​,q2​,⋯,qm​} be a renaming of the goods according to ≻\succ≻. We say ≻\succ≻ and ≻′\succ'≻′ are within a partial slide of each other if there exist x,y∈[m],x≤yx,y\in[m],x\le yx,y∈[m],x≤y s.t.

q1≻q2≻⋯≻qmq1≻′⋯≻′qx−1≻′qx+1≻′⋯≻′qy≻′qx≻′qy+1≻′⋯≻′qmq_1\succ q_2\succ\cdots\succ q_m\\q_1\succ'\cdots\succ'q_{x-1}\succ'q_{x+1}\succ'\cdots\succ'q_y\succ'q_x\succ'q_{y+1}\succ'\cdots\succ'q_mq1​≻q2​≻⋯≻qm​q1​≻′⋯≻′qx−1​≻′qx+1​≻′⋯≻′qy​≻′qx​≻′qy+1​≻′⋯≻′qm​

Let Mt(b)M_t(\mathbf b)Mt​(b) denote the set of available goods right after t−1t-1t−1 goods have been allocated in a run of round-robin(b\mathbf bb).

Lemma 3 states that, at beginning of each step, there is at most one difference between the sets of unallocated goods, and this is difference is either fixed or passed on to the next step, possibly slightly altered.

for all t∈[m+1]t\in[m+1]t∈[m+1].

EFX Equilibria: The Case of 2 Agents

When the agents are not strategic, EFX exist when n≤3n\le3n≤3.

Even for n=3n=3n=3, we are not sure whether there is a polynomial time algorithm.

We consider n=2n=2n=2 in this paper.

Mechanism with EFX Nash Equilibria

A polynomial time algorithm that outputs EFX allocation when we have 2 agents: modified cut-and-choose algorithm in which cut is a variant of envy-cycle-elimination. In this paper, we refer it as “Mod-Cut&Choose”.

This mechanism is not truthful.

This paper shows that although its non-truthful, Mod-Cut&Choose always has at least one PNE for any instance, and all its equilibria are MMS and EFX. (MMS for 2 agent is PMMS, PMMS is EFX.)

Pseudo-code

input: b1,b2\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2b1​,b2​

  1. (E1,E2)=(∅,∅)(E_1,E_2)=(\empty,\empty)(E1​,E2​)=(∅,∅)
  2. (h1,h2,⋯ ,hm)(h_1,h_2,\cdots,h_m)(h1​,h2​,⋯,hm​) is MMM, sorted in decreasing order w.r.t. v1v_1v1​.
  3. for i=1,⋯mi=1,\cdots mi=1,⋯m do // agent 1 partition the bundles
    • j=arg⁡min⁡k∈[2]b1(Ek)j=\arg\min_{k\in[2]}\mathbf b_1(E_k)j=argmink∈[2]​b1​(Ek​)
    • Ej=Ej∪{hi}E_j=E_j\cup\{h_i\}Ej​=Ej​∪{hi​}
  4. ℓ=arg⁡max⁡k∈[2]b2(Ek)\ell=\arg\max_{k\in[2]}\mathbf b_2(E_k)ℓ=argmaxk∈[2]​b2​(Ek​) // agent 2 chooses the bundle
  5. return A=(M╲Eℓ,Eℓ)\mathcal A=(M\diagdown E_\ell,E_\ell)A=(M╲Eℓ​,Eℓ​)

Mod-Cut&Choose algorithm is 5/65/65/6-MMS (tight).

🤔Lemma 4. Let (X1,X2)(X_1,X_2)(X1​,X2​) be a partition of MMM. Agent 111, by bidding accordingly, can force Mod-Cut&Choose to construct E1,E2E_1,E_2E1​,E2​ in for loop s.t. {E1,E2}={X1,X2}\{E_1,E_2\}=\{X_1,X_2\}{E1​,E2​}={X1​,X2​}.

Agent 111 can report in order to create the desired partition (X1,X2)(X_1,X_2)(X1​,X2​) or its permutation (X2,X1)(X_2,X_1)(X2​,X1​).

Case 1: One set has all the goods. Agent 111 declares zero value for all the goods. Then all the goods goes to E1E_1E1​.

Case 2: One set has m−1m-1m−1 goods. Agent 1 declares value 111 for the good that is contained in the set with cardinality 111, and for every good that is contained in the set with cardinality m−1m-1m−1, the agent declares value 1m−1\frac{1}{m-1}m−11​. The first good is added in E1E_1E1​, so E2E_2E2​ is going to get chosen next. According to these values, E2E_2E2​ must get all the remaining goods.

Case 3: The two set have cardinalities k≥2k\ge2k≥2 and m−k≥2m-k\ge2m−k≥2. Agent 111 declares value of one for one of the goods that are contained in the set with cardinality kkk. For every good that is contained in the m−km-km−k set, the agent declares a value of 1+ϵm−k\frac{1+\epsilon}{m-k}m−k1+ϵ​ where 0<ϵ<1m−k−10\lt\epsilon\lt\frac{1}{m-k-1}0<ϵ<m−k−11​, For the rest of the goods, the agent declares ϵk−1\frac{\epsilon}{k-1}k−1ϵ​.

Agent 111 can manipulate bidding to produce min⁡{v1(E1),v1(E2)}=μ1\min\{v_1(E_1),v_1(E_2)\}=\mu_1min{v1​(E1​),v1​(E2​)}=μ1​.

Corollary: Agent 111 can force Mod-Cut&Choose mechanism to construct μ1\mu_1μ1​-partition in for loop.

🎯🤔Theorem 6. For any instance I=({1,2},M,v)\mathcal I=(\{1,2\},M,\mathbf v)I=({1,2},M,v), the Mod-Cut&Choose has at least one PNE. Every PNE of the mechanism is MMS and EFX w.r.t. valuation function v1,v2v_1,v_2v1​,v2​.

Given a partition X=(X1,X2)\mathcal X=(X_1,X_2)X=(X1​,X2​), we define a profile (b1,b2)(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)(b1​,b2​) and show that it is a PNE.

Let b2\mathbf b_2b2​ be the truthful bid of agent 2.

Let b1\mathbf b_1b1​ be the bidding vector that results in Mod-Cut&Choose constructing a partition in

arg⁡max⁡X∈Π2(M)v1(arg⁡min⁡X∈X(X)).\arg\max_{\mathcal X\in\Pi_2(M)}v_1(\arg\min_{X\in\mathcal X}(X)).argX∈Π2​(M)max​v1​(argX∈Xmin​(X)).

Notice that Π2(M)\Pi_2(M)Π2​(M) is finite. By lemma 4, every possible partition can be produced by Mod-Cut&Choose given the appropriate bid vector of agent 111.

So agent 111 forces the partition that maximizes (according v1v_1v1​) the value of the least desirable bundle according to v2v_2v2​.

Now it’s easy to see that given the bidding strategy of agent 222 (truth-telling), there is no deviation for agent 111 that is profitable. Moreover, agent 222 gets the best of the two bundles according to the agent’s valuation function (truth-telling is dominant strategy for agent 222). Thus, there is no profitable deviation for the agent either. Therefore (b1,b2)(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)(b1​,b2​) is a PNE for I\mathcal II.

Suppose a contradiction that there is a PNE b\mathbf bb, for which an agent iii does not achieve the agent’s μi\mu_iμi​ in the allocation returned by Mod-Cut&Choose(b\mathbf bb). If it’s agent 111, then according to Corollary 111, there is a bid vector b1′\mathbf b_1'b1′​ the agent can report so that the algorithm produces a μ1\mu_1μ1​-partition. By deviating to b1′\mathbf b_1'b1′​, regardless of the set given to agent 222, agent 111 ends up with a bundle the agent values at least μ1\mu_1μ1​. This would be a strict improvement over the agent’s current gain, contradicting that b\mathbf bb is PNE.

So it must be the case that agent 222 gets a bundle that strictly less than μ2\mu_2μ2​. Regardless of the partition, by declaring the truthful bid, agent 222 gets a bundle of value at least v2(M)/2v_2(M)/2v2​(M)/2. Then it’s immediate to see that this value is at least μ2\mu_2μ2​, which is a contradiction.

So it’s MMS for 222 agents, thus it’s PMMS, thus EFX.

The Enhanced Fairness of EFX Nash Equilibria

Consider the class of mechanisms that have PNE for every instance, and these equilibria always lead to EFX allocations.

Goal: If these allocations have better fairness guarantees than EFX allocation in general.

2 agents + 4 goods, this paper proved that for every mechanism of this class, all allocations at a PNE are MMS allocations. By Theorem 2, there are instances with just 4 goods in which an EFX allocation is 2/32/32/3-MMS (tight bound).

🤔Lemma 5. Consider an instance with 222 agents and 444 goods. If agent i∈[2]i\in[2]i∈[2] has strictly positive value for 333 or fewer goods, then in every allocation that is EFX from the agent’s point of view, agent iii has value at least μi\mu_iμi​.

Suppose agent iii has positive value for at most 3 goods. The statement is trivial when there is at most one positively valued good as in this case μi=0\mu_i=0μi​=0, and agent iii always gets μi\mu_iμi​ no matter the bundle that agent gets. When agent has a positive value for two goods, in order to consider the allocation as EFX, the agent must get at least one of them. In this case, the agent also achieves the agent’s μi\mu_iμi​ as it is equal to the smaller of the 2 positive values.

Suppose agent iii has positive value for 3 goods, notice that μi\mu_iμi​ in this case is equal to min⁡(\min(min(the largest one, the sum of two smallest values))). If agent iii gets 2 goods, then the agent always derives a value of at least μi\mu_iμi​. If agent gets just one good, then this good must have the highest value; otherwise the agent wouldn’t consider the allocation as EFX. So agent gets value at least μi\mu_iμi​.

🎯🤔Theorem 7. Let M\mathcal MM be a mechanism that has PNE for any instance ([2],M,(v1,v2))([2],\mathcal M,(v_1,v_2))([2],M,(v1​,v2​)) with ∣M∣=4|\mathcal M|=4∣M∣=4 and all these equilibria lead to EFX allocations w.r.t. v1,v2v_1,v_2v1​,v2​. Then, each such EFX allocation is also an MMS allocation.

Suppose for contradiction. There exists a valuation instance v\mathbf vv for which there is a PNE b=(b1,b2)\mathbf b=(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)b=(b1​,b2​) that produces an EFX allocation (A1,A2)(A_1,A_2)(A1​,A2​), where, WLOG, v1(A1)<μ1v_1(A_1)\lt\mu_1v1​(A1​)<μ1​. Rename good to h1,h2,h3,h4h_1,h_2,h_3,h_4h1​,h2​,h3​,h4​ so that valuation is in decreasing order. By lemma 6, A1A_1A1​ must be either a singleton or one of {h2,h3},{h2,h4},{h3,h4}\{h_2,h_3\},\{h_2,h_4\},\{h_3,h_4\}{h2​,h3​},{h2​,h4​},{h3​,h4​}.

  • ∣A1∣=1|A_1|=1∣A1​∣=1. Because (A1,A2)(A_1,A_2)(A1​,A2​) is an EFX allocation and all goods have positive value according to v1v_1v1​, it is easy to see that A1={h1}A_1=\{h_1\}A1​={h1​}. Then again because we have an EFX allocation, v1(h1)≥v1({h2,h3})v_1(h_1)\ge v_1(\{h_2,h_3\})v1​(h1​)≥v1​({h2​,h3​}). The latter implies v1(A1)≥μ1v_1(A_1)\ge\mu_1v1​(A1​)≥μ1​ by second inequality of lemma 6.

  • A1={h2,h3}A_1=\{h_2,h_3\}A1​={h2​,h3​}. Because A1A_1A1​ is EFX-satisfied, v1(A1)≥v1(h1)v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(h_1)v1​(A1​)≥v1​(h1​). Similar to case 1, this implies v1(A1)≥μ1v_1(A_1)\ge\mu_1v1​(A1​)≥μ1​.

  • A1={h2,h4}A_1=\{h_2,h_4\}A1​={h2​,h4​} or {h3,h4}\{h_3,h_4\}{h3​,h4​}. Consider different v∗\mathbf v^*v∗, where agents have same values over the goods. The valuation function v∗v^*v∗ is defined

    v∗(hj)={1.2 j=11 j∈{2,3}0.1 j=4v^*(h_j)=\begin{cases}1.2\ j=1\\1\ j\in\{2,3\}\\0.1\ j=4\end{cases}v∗(hj​)=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​1.2 j=11 j∈{2,3}0.1 j=4​

    There are only 2 EFX allocations ({h1,h4},{h2,h3}),({h2,h3},{h1,h4})(\{h_1,h_4\},\{h_2,h_3\}),(\{h_2,h_3\},\{h_1,h_4\})({h1​,h4​},{h2​,h3​}),({h2​,h3​},{h1​,h4​}). According to assumption, there must be a bid b∗\mathbf b^*b∗ that is a PNE of M\mathcal MM for this valuation profile. Because we require PNE to be EFX, M(b∗)\mathcal M(\mathbf b^*)M(b∗) must be one of these allocations.

    Observe that the value that agent 2​ derives in these allocations is at most 2.

    discuss on bundle of agent 1 accordingly.

    • A1A_1A1​ is singleton. Contradicts PNE.
    • A1A_1A1​ has 3 items. Contradicts PNE.
    • A1A_1A1​ is one of 12,13,14,2312,13,14,2312,13,14,23. By lemma 6, this contradicts MMS.
    • A1A_1A1​ is one of 24,3424,3424,34. Contradicts PNE.

Thus EFX allocations here are all MMS allocations. Q.E.D.

🤔Lemma 6. For N,M,v1N,M,v_1N,M,v1​ as earlier, we have vi({h1,h4})≥μ1v_i(\{h_1,h_4\})\ge\mu_1vi​({h1​,h4​})≥μ1​ and max⁡{vi(h1),vi({h2,h3})}≥μ1\max\{v_i(h_1),v_i(\{h_2,h_3\})\}\ge\mu_1max{vi​(h1​),vi​({h2​,h3​})}≥μ1​.

For m≥5m\ge5m≥5, theorem 7 is not work. Because there are cases don’t lead to contradiction.

We need relaxation on MMS to α\alphaα-MMS, but here α>2/3\alpha\gt2/3α>2/3.

🎯🤔Theorem 8. Let M\mathcal MM be a mechanism that has PNE for any instance ([2],M,(v1,v2))([2],\mathcal M,(v_1,v_2))([2],M,(v1​,v2​)) and all these equilibria lead to EFX allocation w.r.t. v1,v2v_1,v_2v1​,v2​. Then, each such EFX allocation is also an α\alphaα-MMS with α>2/3\alpha\gt2/3α>2/3.

Suppose for contradiction: there exists such a mechanism M\mathcal MM and an instance ({1,2},M,(v1,v2))(\{1,2\},M,(v_1,v_2))({1,2},M,(v1​,v2​)) for which there is a PNE b=(b1,b2)\mathbf b=(\mathbf b_1,\mathbf b_2)b=(b1​,b2​) that results in an EFX allocation A\mathcal AA, where vi(Ai)≤2μi/3v_i(A_i)\le2\mu_i/3vi​(Ai​)≤2μi​/3 for at least one i∈[2]i\in[2]i∈[2]. WLOG, assume v1(A1)≤2μ1/3v_1(A_1)\le2\mu_1/3v1​(A1​)≤2μ1​/3. By Theorem 2, this implies v1(A1)=2μ1/3v_1(A_1)=2\mu_1/3v1​(A1​)=2μ1​/3. Thus v1(A2)≥4μi/3v_1(A_2)\ge4\mu_i/3v1​(A2​)≥4μi​/3 because v1(M)≥2μ1v_1(M)\ge2\mu_1v1​(M)≥2μ1​ by definition of MMS.

Initially, we restrict # goods with positive value in A2A_2A2​. Let S⊆A2S\subseteq A_2S⊆A2​ be the set of such goods. Let ∣S∣=k|S|=k∣S∣=k and notice that kkk can’t be 000 or 111. Finally, let x∈arg⁡min⁡g∈Sv1(g)x\in\arg\min_{g\in S}v_1(g)x∈argming∈S​v1​(g) be a minimum valued good for agent 111 in SSS. We have

23μ1=v1(A1)≥v1(S╲{x})≥v1(S)−v1(S)k=k−1kv1(A2)≥k−1k43μ1,\frac{2}{3}\mu_1=v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(S\diagdown\{x\})\ge v_1(S)-\frac{v_1(S)}{k}=\frac{k-1}{k}v_1(A_2)\ge\frac{k-1}{k}\frac{4}{3}\mu_1,32​μ1​=v1​(A1​)≥v1​(S╲{x})≥v1​(S)−kv1​(S)​=kk−1​v1​(A2​)≥kk−1​34​μ1​,

where the first inequality follows from EFX. Observe that k≤2k\le2k≤2, this implies k=2k=2k=2.

… Yet another long proof

Discussion

This paper discusses fair division with indivisible goods to a set of strategic agents.

Surprisingly, there exists strong impossibilities for truthful mechanisms. The paper shows that there exist mechanisms that have PNE for every instance, and at the same time the PNE allocation have strong guarantees w.r.t. true valuations.

Possible directions for future work:

  • Algorithm that compute EF1 allocations for richer valuation function domains (Envy-cycle elimination) in strategic setting.

    • Does there exist pure or mixed Nash Equilibria?
    • If there exist NE, does it still maintain fairness properties at the NE?

  • Theorem 7&8 leave an open problem: MMS guarantee that the equilibria of mechanisms that always have PNE and these are EFX.

    • suspect: corresponding allocations are not always MMS.
    • For every such mechanism that runs in polynomial time, finding a best response of an agent is NP. For n≥3n\ge3n≥3 the problem is absolutely non-trivial.

  • The complexity for computing best response. Want to know if best response dynamics always converge to a PNE or there might be cyclic behavior?
entry.summary:
Objective: Investigate strategic aspects of fair division, considering Pure Nash equilibria and fairness.

Activities: Review the p

entry.title: 西语学习 A1 Unidad 2 ¿Cómo estás?
entry.content:
Vocabulario

gracias f.pl. 谢谢

amigo, a m.f. 朋友

director, ra m.f. 经理

teléfono m. 电话

bombero, a m.f. 消防员

副词

muy adv. 很

bien adv. 好

动词

estar intr. 在；处于

estar 的变位：estoy - estás - está - estamos - estáis - están

物主形容词（非重读，放在名词的前面）

⚠️物主形容词修饰复数名词时，词尾加 s

我的 mi

你的 tu

TA的、您的 su

我们的 nuestro, nuestra

你们的 vuestro, vuestra

TA们的 su

指示代词，“这个，这些”

单数 阳性 este 阴性 esta

复数 阳性 estos 阴性 estas

定冠词，表特指

单数 阳性 el 阴性 la

复数 阳性 los 阴性 las

练习

¿Dónde está tu director?

¿Dónde está tu directora?

¿Dónde están tus directores?

¿Dónde están tus directoras?

¿Dónde está vuestro director?

¿Dónde está vuestra directora?

¿Dónde están vuestros directores?

¿Dónde están vuestras directoras?

Este es mi amigo. El amigo es italiano.

Esta es mi amiga. La amiga es italiana.

Estos son mis amigos. Los amigos son italianos.

Estas son mis amigas. Las amigas son italianas.

Este es el estudiante de chino. El estudiante está muy bien.

Esta es la estudiante de chino. La estudiante está muy bien.

Estos son los estudiantes de chino. Los estudiantes están muy bien.

Estas son las estudiantes de chino. Las estudiantes están muy bien.

打招呼常用语

Buenos días. 早上好。

Buenas tardes. 下午好。

Buenas noches. 晚上好/晚安。

¿Cómo estás? 你好吗？

¿Qué tal? （你/您/你们/诸位）好吗？

Mucho gusto. 很⾼兴（认识你/您）。

Encantado/a. 很⾼兴认识（你/您）。

Adiós. 再见。

Hasta luego. 待会儿见。

Hasta mañana. 明天见。

接打电话

¿Diga? 喂？

¿Con quién hablo? 你是谁？

¿Quién es? 这是谁？

¿De parte de quién? 你是谁？（正式）

句型：主语 + ser + 名词和形容词

注意：西语中形容词要随其修饰的名词进行阴阳性和单复数变化。

  • El cocido y el gazpacho son platos españoles.
  • Neymar y Marcelo son futbolistas brasileños.
  • La pizza y la pasta son comidas italianas.
  • Oxford y Cambridge son ciudades británicas.
entry.summary:
Vocabulario

gracias f.pl. 谢谢

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.2 11-12 Planer for ferie og fridage
entry.content:
Efterårsferie

sydpå 向南 副词

nordpå 向北

østpå 向东

vestpå 向西

lige nu 现在

herfra 从这里

bytur 城市游览

svamp -en -e -ene 蘑菇，真菌，海绵

teater -et, teatre, teatrene 剧院

gå i teatret 去剧院

eller sådan noget 相当于英语的 or something like that

lad os bare gøre det 让我们这样做吧

复习表示建议、提议的表达

Hvad skal vi lave …?

Hvad synes du, vi skal lave?

  • Skal vi ikke + inf.?
  • Vi kan f.eks. + inf.
  • Vi kunne måske + inf.
  • Jeg synes, vi skal/skulle + inf.
  • Hvad siger du til at + inf.?

Svar:

  • Det kan vi godt.
  • Jeg ved ikke rigtig.
  • Det synes jeg ikke.
  • Nej, det har jeg ikke så meget lyst til.

Svar + alternativt forslag:

  • Skal vi ikke hellere …
  • Jeg synes hellere, vi skal …
  • Eller hvad med at inf.

Nyt forslag:

  • Vi kan også …
  • Vi kunne måske også …

作业：剪切并排序，成为一个完整的对话

A: Hvad siger du til at rejse nordpå? Vi kunne for eksempel tage til Nordnorge.

B: Hvad skulle vi lave dér?

A: Vi kunne vandre i bjergene og sove i telt.

B: Nej, det har jeg ikke meget lyst til. Det er for primitivt at sove i telt, og det er for hårdt at vandre. Jeg vil hellere sydpå, hvor der er sol og strand.

A: Jeg ved ikke rigtig. Jeg synes det er kedeligt at ligge på stranden. Skal vi ikke hellere tage på storbyferie?

B: Hvilken storby tænker du på?

A: Hvad siger du til Stockholm?

B: Nej, der har jeg været. Jeg vil hellere til Athen.

A: Nej, der er for mange mennesker. Hvad med Berlin?

B: Ja, det kunne jeg godt tænke mig. Hvordan synes du vi skal bo?

A: Hvad siger du til at prøve Airbnb?

B: Ja, lad os gøre det.

Fremtid og ferieplaner

Carl og Johan planlægger en rejse

Han er sikker på, at … 他确信……

af sted 离开

mulighed -en -er -erne 可能，可能性

ørkenlandskab -et -er -erne 沙漠景观

dyreliv -et - -ene 野生动物

beslutte -r -de -t 决定

kyst -en -er -erne 沿海

Fremtid

有的时候可以使用现在时表将来。

Plan

  • skal + retning (sted)
  • ska + handling (verbum 2)

Et ønske / En intention

  • vil + retning (sted)
  • vil + handling (verbum 2)

Hovedsætning og ledsætning

Ledsætning først:

Når + S + V, V + S (inversion)

Ledsætning sidst:

S + V, når + S + V

fordi 因为 连接从句

  • for 连词 因为 连接主句

når 当……的时候（表示现在和将来）；一……就……

da 当……的时候（表示过去）

hvis 如果

mens 一边……一边……

før 在……之前

efter at 在……之后

til/indtil 直到

siden 自从
